I mean by that is when a black writer gives him/her self the permission to write something that they do not allow other non-Black or non-ethnic writers to do.how many times white writers were backlashed because "they killed the black character too soon" or "they made the only Asian character evil" or "they werent creative in naming their POC characters"but it was Ok for this writer to take the only Chinese character in this book, gives him a name like "Lin" and make him a drunk, a gambler, a bad parent, a bad husband, and a child beater. not to mention selling her child to save his lifeand it only took him losing 2 wives and a daughter to check back on his life??????????I wonder if a white author did that with the only black character or the only POC character, what would have happened?6- the struggles felt trivial. Oh your parents did not agree with you immediately on your sexual choices, oh poor baby!Oh your parents hid their background truth from you to protect you and give you the best life, HOW DARE THEY?Oh your sister did not call you after you did not stand up with her, how sorry we are to you?I mean, were these really worth writing a book about????on the other hand, what Covey went through was the center and should have been the main focus, but the story deflected so many times you almost forget about her7- the underline message that this book is trying to say that parents, all their sacrifices and hardship, all their work and caring, means nothing if they did not agree with your choices.Benny's parents wanted the best for her, made sure that she would go to good college and have education, but how dare they! Benny knows what is best for her, she stormed out of the house after they tolerating her fluxuating from one major to another. and to think that she would have accomplished something! Oh NO, SHE WAS A LOSER. she refused to let her parents dictate her life but allowed abusive men to do that! how smartplease remember that PARENTS DO KNOW BEST sometimes8- non of the other characters, besides Covey and Gibbs, were likable or reliatable. As a matter of fact, they were selfish and self-centered. every one was thinking about themselves.I found myself skipping many pages once i reached the 50% mark and just wanted to finish this bookeven the happy ending wasnt all that

title: What My Bones Know: A Memoir of Healing from Complex Trauma
author: Stephanie Foo
Random House Audio
reviews: I am a therapist specializing in cPTSD.  There are many well-written aspects of this book and it is well-researched.  However, as a psychotherapist specializing in PTSD and cPTSD, I have a few issues:1.  Just because someone has a PhD does not make them a good therapist.  It’s not about book smarts or education.  It’s about how one can connect to and work with the relational aspects of trauma.  These comments about MA vs PhD pissed me off.  I am not a PhD, mostly because I have an education background in biochemistry and neuroscience (undergraduate degrees), having worked in biotechnology for 15 years.  I don’t need a PhD to have knowledge and skill to address relational trauma.2.  I am a certified EMDR therapist, trained in 2001.  I have been using EMDR therapy in my practice for over 20 years with consistently effective results in addressing cPTSD.  I also have a cohort of excellent somatically-based colleagues who also effectively treat cPTSD, most of us lowly MA or MS-level LPC’s or LCSW’s (not PhD’s).  Not all EMDR therapists are created (or trained) equally.  Check out Dr. Arielle Schwartz, a friend and exceptionally skilled colleague.  Yes, a PhD but that’s not what makes her exceptional.  Check out her books and videos.3.  I am also trained in IFS.  “Mr. Sweater Vest” is not representative of IFS, as presented in this book. At all, sadly.  “The Hulk” as presented here is a “part” that served as a protector.  Too bad it apparently wasn’t addressed.  And no mention of Self energy?There are many poignant aspects of this well-written book.  I have compassion and appreciation for the author and her courage to heal.  However, I am frustrated by her cynicism and negativity, painting a slanted portrayal of effective approaches to healing cPTSD.

I’m an LMSW whose focus in grad school was mental health and substance abuse. I’ve read a lot of books on trauma and its innumerable affects on the body and the brain. I’m also someone who has been on my own healing journey and recovery from trauma. This is the best book I’ve read on this topic. The honesty, the lived-experience, and the truth Foo shines light on regarding the flaws in our nation’s healthcare system and how “mental healthcare” is one of the faultiest systems of all. Foo walks the fine line between artful storytelling and researched informing. The most refreshing part of the book is that, for once, we’re hearing from someone who *isn’t* an “expert” or a PhD of psychology or someone who has the knowledge/academic background/clout and the prestige and power that comes with those things. Somehow, hearing the story of someone who went through hell, survived, and not only lived to tell the tale, but relentlessly pursued her own healing and never gave up, was far more impactful for me than all the “data,” “research,” and “studies” of experts.This is an excellent book for anyone who wants to heal, does not want to be a victim of their circumstances, and meets their past with curiosity. Highly recommend.

Well, I guess once I’m done crying I can explain how much this book meant to me. I stayed up until 4 am last night willing myself to put it down, but I knew I couldn’t. It’s a wonderful, horrible, sad, joyful journey into and through trauma. It resonated for me more than the many technical manuals I’ve read because Stephanie shared her personal story, her own journey, and her desperate need for understanding and healing, and it became intimately familiar and relatable, and empowering. Honestly, it was the perfect book for me at exactly the right time. I’m bouncing around on the same recovery boat, and it was a beautiful reminder that we can (and should strive to) paddle fiercely until we recover our true selves after complex trauma.I don’t know…I’m a trauma-informed therapist and a part of me wants to address the book from this professional aspect, but honestly? As a complex trauma survivor I just want to sit and feel good about Stephanie’s story. I want to enjoy how seen and heard it made me feel to read it. I want to bask in the delight of her discoveries and keep noticing how much us survivors all follow the same basic trail until we reach some level of enlightenment. I feel…good after reading this. I feel more aware of how trauma impacts specific communities, and I feel validated personally. Reading this gave me some peace.

This book was finally the book I needed about C-PTSD. I’ve read many other books about it, most of which were written by psychologists or other scientific professionals. This is the first one I have read by someone who LIVES with C-PTSD but who has begun to fight against it successfully.As someone who has recently been diagnosed with C-PTSD but who has been living with it her entire life, just knowing I’m not alone would have been enough good to come out of this book. But by reading this book, I was given hope, strategies to use, statistics and information, and the motivation to keep fighting the “beast” she writes about.I would never wish the events that happen to cause C-PTSD on any human. But this author took the awful beast and is bringing so much good to the world, so the pain is not in vain.

This was not the book I thought it would be and yet I could not put it down. I love Stephanie’s exhaustive list of healing practices and saw myself through her no nonsense attitude. Her journey is remarkable and I have nothing but praise for letting us glimpse into her windy path to healing. Her realizations with Dr. Ham were mind blowing.

title: Nightcrawling: A novel
author: Leila Mottley
reviews: Kiara, the narrator, is three months away from her eighteenth birthday and already dealing with grownup problems. She witnessed her dad wasting away from the illness that ultimately took him four years after he was released from prison, while her mother is doing time for an event the family never speaks of. Kiara is a high school dropout out of necessity, working a few hours a week at a local liquor store just to get by, while her older brother, Marcus, wastes his time dreaming of making it big as a rapper, like their uncle Ty.Just as the condominium they have lived in her entire life is being sold and the rent doubled, her part-time job hours are cut and she has no way to keep her head above water without help from her reluctant brother. To make matters worse, her ten-year-old neighbor, Trevor, has been deserted by his drug addict mother, and Kiara, having witnessed his birth and having known him all his life, feels responsible for his fate as well. Running out of options, it’s only a matter of time until Kiara starts to see her body as a way to keep them afloat, but even that option will have unforeseen consequences for her and those she holds dear.Gritty, equal parts anger-inducing and heartbreaking, it’s hard to believe that events like what this book depict may have happened in real life. Soaring prose and vividly rendered characters make Nightcrawling a triumph of storytelling. The Booker nomination was well-deserved.

Nightcrawling is a poetic screed, a nightmare turned lullaby that will submerge you in the same feces filled swimming pool that sits like a monument – “… the way the chlorine and feces have become part of the air, the natural scent of the apartment.”It is a testament to place and time.“None of us have ever set foot in the pool for as long as I been here,” says 17-year-old Kiara, who along with her brother, Marcus, attempt to survive in Oakland. Abandoned by their mother, who attempted to kill herself after neglecting her infant daughter; the infant later found dead in that very pool. Their father died years earlier.Repulsed? Heard this before? Well, keep reading.Nightcrawling is a contemplation of what it means to be vulnerable, unprotected, and unseen, says the author, the 2018 Oakland Youth Poet Laureate, Leila Mottley, whose work has been featured in the New York Times and Oprah Daily. Nightcrawling  is a 2022 Oprah’s Book Club pick and has also recently (announced July 26, 2022) been long-listed for the 2022 Booker Prize (the leading literary award in the English-speaking world), with 20-year Mottley, the youngest ever.Each sentence is a poem that wafts, delays, and immerses you in the mind of the novel’s heroine, Kiara.Nightcrawling exposes the trauma without becoming bogged down in it; at once, an element of hope amidst a seemingly endless string of roadblocks including family, long ago friends turned dizzying acquaintances, drugs, crime and prostitution.It is the familiar animus of our time.“Letting the streets have you is like planning your own funeral. Streets always find you in the daylight, when you least expect them to. Night crawling up to me when the sun’s out.”Kiara has to pay the rent but no one, other than the occasional side job, will hire her. Her slightly older brother Marcus tries but is too caught up in his own ego and pride and more importantly, the abandonment he feels from not only his mother and father but his ostensibly well to do Uncle Ty, who lives in LA, and has had success in the rap game.A game Marcus wants to give his all but his all is too little to ward off the lure of the street to which he inevitably succumbs.To Kiara, “Street money's still money,” and what begins as a misunderstanding grants Kiara a sense of power. A power over men through the use of what she feels is the only thing she has left.“Only thing worse than a untamed man is a man on the edge of it.”In 2015, when Mottley was a young teenager in Oakland, a story broke describing how members of the Oakland Police Department, and several other police departments in the Bay Area, had participated in the sexual exploitation of a young woman and attempted to cover it up – author’s note.“I’m starting to think there is no such thing as a good cop, that the uniform erases the person inside it.”But Nightcrawling is less about cops than it is about humanity and degradation; the will to survive. Here, cops are simply the sledgehammer that keeps hammering even when there are no more holes to fill.“The swimming pool is filled with dog sh*t and Dee’s laughter mocks us at dawn.”But it is in the darkness brought to light, the true impact of Nightcrawling “that art is the way we imprint ourselves onto the world so there is no way to erase us.”

At the age of 17, our main character Kiara is on her own. Father dead, mother in jail, older brother refusing to take any real responsibility. Playing stand-in mother to a neighbor's kid, she carries the world on her shoulders as she tries to keep the apartment and survive. This is a story of desperation, of being pushed into a corner and how one bad decision can get you stuck in an untenable situation. Through her found family, Kiara finds a reason to keep going as well as (eventually) the support she needs to move on. "Nightcrawling" deals with so many issues -- poverty, abandonment, exploitation, racism, becoming an adult and resilience. No 17 year old should have all this on their shoulders. Mottley does an amazing job of creating a fully realized main character and showing how she navigates the situation and how she arrives at her decisions.This book is made even more interesting in retrospect knowing that it was inspired by a real case of police exploitation of a young black woman in Oakland, CA and the fact that Mottley, who is from Oakland, started writing this (her debut) novel when she was 16, with its publication when she was only 19. I look forward to reading more from this young woman who evidently is very talented.
This book was good from beginning to end. I read 4 chapters the first day. Can't believe the author was 16/17 when she wrote it. She's an amazing writer.  Looking forward to her next book.

I appreciated the storyline of this book, though it was hard to read knowing this has happened and will continue to happen. I also appreciated SOME of the poetic aspects of the author's writing style and all of the imagery, but it, at many times, became annoying. There was just an overly excessive use of figurative language (almost forced) that lost me and made it irritating to read. I am happy that I pushed through and completed the novel.
An insider view of street walking or turning tricks and how and why young women get involved.

title: By Hands Now Known: Jim Crow's Legal Executioners
author: Margaret A. Burnham
reviews: The treatment of black citizens in America has been of interest to me since learning of segregation.  I have read all that I can find about the civil rights movement and how black people had to navigate the white south after Reconstruction.  By Hands Now Known provides accounts of black men being mirdered by white law enforcement, bus drivers and others with impunity and with no legal consequences.  It’s difficult to understand the hatred and mistreatment that black people endured for the sake of segregation.  And the Federal Government standing by allowing black men, women and children in the south to be lynched indiscriminately, soldiers who fought for democracy in other countries and couldn’t find it at home.  I’m more enlightened about the suffering and pain that black people have endured for centuries in this nation.  And today who are we making America great again for?

The book discusses the injustices and murderous horrors inflicted on Black people during the days of Jim Crow.  The violence was much more pervasive than is commonly known.  The book also discusses how the laws enacted during Reconstruction to protect Blacks were eviscerated or ignored.  Finally, the book discusses reparations, and specifically how the descendents of those directly affected by specific instances of violence, including murder, might be recompensed for the evils done to their families. I'd give five stars except that the book is unclear at the beginning as to just what the author's purpose is and because the discussions of crucial US Supreme Court cases are, overall, somewhat vague.

It's no wonder White People don't want true American history taught. Someone's mamaw and pop-pop are likely to be in those old photographs of Black bodies being treated no better than the dirt they walked on.
as expected

I read this with a basic knowledge of lynching and police violence towards black Americans. These stories made it  so personal. I am already committed to reparations but for anyone who is not this book is a compelling case In favor of reparations. These are incredible stories very well told.

Gives specific instances of the failure of law to address illegal murder of Blacks...rendering them invisible and destroying whole families. Those who think today's profiling of Blacks by law enforcement could benefit from seeing its roots in Jim Crow "law". It is time to consider reparations to set the record straight.

Shows once again how the FEDERAL, STATE and LOCAL GOVERNMENT, had failed the black community by not protecting them. These book only hits a small percentage all the injustices people have to endure continuous to this day.

This is a difficult book to read.  Other recent books in what might be called the "Critical Race Theory" canon - "The Sum of Us," "Caste," or "Devil in the Grove" - are positively light reading compared to this one.  The book is organized a number of "tentpoles" of how Blacks were not really free, until very recently.  The best way I can summarize it is to say it provides some meat and bones to go with what have become memes, e.g. Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat, but how many people realize that for decades before that, Blacks had resisted segregation on buses, often paying with their lives.  Or the Great Migration is often portrayed as innocuous as the swallows returning to Capistrano, when it was for many a flight of refugees to relative safety when they had a target on their backs for, say, trying to register to vote.And it does a great job of getting one to understand how the federal government failed to protect Black people - soldiers posted to southern army bases who ran afoul of "Southern Ways,", or courts calling attacks on Black people a matter for the states and not a violation of constitutional rights.  We read about a number of Supreme Court rulines that make one understand the Plessy v. Ferguson or Korematsu weren't the only dreadful decisions from that body.It's dense and difficult, and unfortunately the writer hasn't made the podcast rounds, but this book deserves a lot more attention.  And inclusion on a lot of history class reading lists.

title: When in Rome: A Novel
author: Sarah Adams
reviews: Amelia is Rae Rose, pop star.  She is finding she is not happy with her life, so she decides to take a vacation without telling anyone.  Audrey Hepburn is her go-to movie star.  She decides to go to Rome like Audrey did in Roman Holiday, but Italy is too far, so she goes to Rome, Kentucky.  Her car breaks down on the outskirts of town.  A man knocks on her window, but she will not unwind the window or get out of her car.  He gets frustrated and walks back to his house where her car is parked on his front lawn.  Noah, the man, decides it is too hot for her to stay in her car, so he asks Mabel, his grandmother's friend, to vouch for his good character.  After talking to Mabel, Amelia gets out of the car and stays in Noah's extra room for the night, figuring she will get to the bed and breakfast in town the next morning.  She finds it will take two weeks to fix her car, so Noah reluctantly offers his spare room.  Both are attracted but know she will only temporarily be in town, so they make rules and build walls to keep from getting close.  Will it work?I enjoyed this book.  It was fun watching Amelia get under Noah's skin as she imitated him, discovered things about him, constantly chattering at him, and all the other little things she does.  Noah's been burned by an ex-fiancée.  He does not trust easily.  Even knowing she's only temporarily in his life, he still falls for her.  Amelia also falls for Noah.  She has been spoiled living the pop star life and knows little of how to take care of herself.  But with Noah, she knows she is safe.  I liked watching them set up their rules and walls and seeing them fall.  I liked the vulnerability each brings to their relationship.  Amelia learns a lot about herself while in Rome.  She starts to find the joy of music again as well as the comfort of safe people in her life.  Noah also learns about himself while trying not to fall in love.I loved the town and its people.  A bunch of gossips who have good hearts and protect those they see as theirs.  I loved Noah's sisters.  Each was different in personality, but each backed the others,  The characters were quirky.  They were fun.  They saw love when it hit their town.I look forward to reading more of this author's work.

Overwhelmed by her career and obligations Amelia, aka Rae Rose to her adoring fans, decides to leave town and spend some time in a small town a few hours from her home in Nashville, but when her car breaks down in the middle of the night in what looks like a back road without cell service, she panics and start rethinking her whole strategy.  It’s then when she meets Noah, the grumpy man who will change her life.I had never read this author and this book was an amazing surprise.  Being an all-time fan of classic movies and having Roman Holiday high on my favorites list, I was wary of the plot at first as I’ve read huge flops claiming to be a take on the movie, but this time was the fabulous exception as Ms. Adams wrote a delightful, fun and heartfelt tale where a woman escaping from the crushing pressures of her life finds herself and love in the most unexpected place of all.The book is beautifully written and, while it was obviously inspired by the movie, keeps its originality and greatly respects the source.  It was refreshing to read a story that is fun, sweet and engaging from beginning to end and not a run of the mill book that starts as a rom-com and ends up as a soggy attempt at being funny.Noah Walker is the perfect book boyfriend, his sisters and the rest of the town a complete hoot and sweet, lost, misguided Amelia is a joy to read as she navigates the hardships of finding her voice and taking charge of her life.I truly loved reading When in Rome and will be looking up more books by the author soon.5 absolutely glorious stars

When In Rome by Sarah Adams⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️/5🔥/5This book was so good. I immediately fell in love with the characters and the setting. In the description of the small town, I felt as though it was a place I’d been before. Very light on the spice, but the romance is strong regardless. This story was sweet and light, the type to make you fall for happily ever after all over again. 💜Rae Rose is exhausted by the pressures of fame and the constant demand of her time. She decides to sneak away and find herself, when her car breaks down in Noah Walker’s yard. He’s not the Prince Charming you’d expect, but he has a sort of small town chivalry that no one can resist. He’s been burned by a passerby before, so will he be able to open his home and heart to opportunity again?

Actual Rating: 4.5 stars!This was such a fun read and my current favorite out of Adams's books! I absolutely adored Amelia and related so much to her obsession with Audrey Hepburn. I spent my teenage years watching and rewatching Hepburn's movies. I found Amelia just as relatable and, honestly, reading this right before the Eras Tour starts (and comparing Amelia to a younger TSwift) just gave me all the feels.This book was the perfect balance of MC growth and romance and now I need to go read every single book from Sarah Adams's backlist before May when Annie and Will's book is published!

Literally so wholesome cute and funny. An easy read that’s makes you giggle the whole time. Even though it’s cheesy as heck it’s cheesy in a good way. So much banter I loved it. 4 stars only because it’s not some literary masterpiece but it is a perfect rom com.

title: Memphis: A Novel
author: Tara M. Stringfellow
reviews: Told from the perspective of multiple generations, at different times, of a family of women from Memphis. Here we meet Joan, Miriam, August, Hazel, and Della, as well as other characters that enrich, weave, and shape their lives. History is woven into these pages, along with different perspectives of times and situations. After all, what looks the same to a 10 year old and a 35 year old? Time also shifts things. What people experience and think, of past and present, as they grow older. What it means to be a black person, but especially a black woman, in the heart and heat of Memphis. What experiences will shape each of these strong, gifted black women?I genuinely can’t say enough about this book. It’s not overly long, but it is rich in everything. 30 pages in, I was laughing at some things, but I also knew I would be crying before long, and I was right. This is beautiful, and sad, and funny, and real. I loved the author mixing in bits of history as she told this story from all of these different angles. Even when you guess at what is going to happen, or what has already happened, it still grabs you by the heart when it does. The characters are human, flawed and wonderful. Learning as they go. Finding the beauty in the anger. If I could give this more stars, I would. I couldn’t put the book down, the plot and the author’s unique storytelling kept me riveted.In addition, this version has a poem for Gianna Floyd, a recipe, some background on the author and the book, and pages of wonderful thank yous. It also has questions for a discussion with your book club. I hope Tara M. Stringfellow publishes more books, she has a big fan in me.

This book is something special.  Yes, it has a lot of the things we white people know to be part of the black experience in this country, but nothing feels trite or repetitive about it.  It feels woven in a colorful, joyful, painful way that I’ve never quite seen.  A little like the poetry the author references in her afterwords.  And the poem at the end- read through that horrible obtrusion Amazon puts at the not-quite-end of books.  They cut off a lot of goo stuff by doing that.  It would be beautiful if they somehow did an illustrated version of this.
This book took me a long time to start...my own personal trauma. It was beyond worth it. I have now gifted this book to two other friends. It is definitely a must read.
A good story about different  generations of strong black women living in the south and raising their children

This novel is beautiful! Being from the Memphis area and reading the descriptions that are so elegant but true to life of Memphis and the Mid-South was refreshing. The story weaves a family tale of strong despite struggle, of warriors who hurt too, of family, the Black Family in America. I give it 5 Stars and will tell everyone I know to read it. Bravo Tara M. Stringfellow!!!! Bravo!!!!
Great characters and descriptions of life in the south through the eyes of strong black women. Great book. Pleas read

Memphis is a great 1st novel by the author in a story that spans a 70-year time period. This  is a powerful saga of four women who survive through family secrets and the hardships of black love.  These women forge through impossible situations involving incest and domestic abuse. Nevertheless, I felt that the author did not deal with the damages and effects that abuse can have on the victim and the abuser.  The author's writing style is excellent and I was drawn into the story by her awesome symbolism and prose.  However I was sometimes thrown off by the jumping back and forth in time periods.  Although these women show perseverance at times it seems as if their emotions are stifled and the full story is not told.  Maybe she's leaning toward a second novel to give us a more in depth picture of the  main characters and the other 41 characters in the book.

Wow, this book started off as a very slow read for me and sometimes difficult. Because it bounce between women age and time zones. But it has a powerful message and that message is black women have always been the backbone of this country, we are strong, we are resilience and fierce. To all the black man that may read this book if you got a strong black woman you can do anything, cherish her and love her. Ms Stringfellow  love your book and I love your writing.  I look forward to reading some more of your work. God bless

title: Like a Rolling Stone: A Memoir
author: Jann  Wenner
reviews: I loved this book - I'm a baby boomer musician and have been an avid RS reader since day 1. My musical tastes and political leanings have always been in sync with Wenner's - his writing about music, political and environmental causes has always been fantastic, so why would his autobiography be any different?I had imagined, I guess, that he knew the rich and famous, but he knew EVERYONE! If you want an adventure behind the scenes of a master chronicler of popular culture, you will love this book!

Jann Wenner...Narcissism: selfishness, involving a sense of entitlement, a lack of empathy, and a need for admiration. That sums up Jann's personality type, and the main take away from reading this book.The early days of Rolling Stone are fascinating, because the music that it covered was phenomenal, and transformed a generation - a unique stitch in time!But those days did not last forever, and Jann has no real second act in Rock & Roll to report on. So Wenner writes about Bruce, Bono and others that kissed his ass, and vice versa. And his privileged life, going corporate, missing his corporate jet, and sex life.Boring...it ain't no substitute for the early days for Rock & Roll and the musicians that gave it life - sometimes, sadly,  literally.  Sex, drugs, and Rock & Roll - hard to beat it - too bad, Jann didn't spend more time writing about the behind the scenes action instead of his vacations, motorcycles and self obsession with himself.

The Rolling Stone was the first national publication that spoke to my generation. It connected us. This book by it's founder is a journey through the music, politics, and people of those unique times.

This is a great autobiography. Not only about the author, but also about the business he created. It was fascinating to find out the details about the magazine I grew up reading and the insights into the artists and issues it covered.

Well written memoir by the founding editor of Rolling Stone magazine.  Wenner gives a brief bio of his childhood and college years, which are actually pertinent to his path as co-founder of RS,  which is widely considered the de facto journal of the hippie/Rock and Roll scene.The birth, growing pains, and maturing of the magazine is nicely woven into the zeitgeist of the 60's and into the 70s, 80s, and so on.  He talks about his interactions and friendships with people including Mick Jagger, the Beatles, Bob Dylan and other musicians and cultural figures (e.g., Timothy Leary) of the era.  He also spends quite a few pages on his interactions with Annie Leibovitz and Hunter S. Thompson, whose careers he helped establish.  His description of his first meeting with Thompson (p. 118-9) is hysterical.  Later he describes his (and the magazines) maturation and move to New York from San Francisco.  Along with the move came friendships with folks Like Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, Andy Warhol, Tom Wolfe.Only reason for 4 stars instead of 5, the book at times (especially in the last half) gets a little disjointed and verbose. Wenner's ego seems to take over as he talks about vacations with famous people on his private jet, a cross country motorcycle trip, and other anecdotes that really don’t have much if anything to do with the magazine, music, investigative reporting or politics.  Of course if you hang around with people like Bill and Hillary Clinton, Jackie O., Bono, Mick, Richard Gere and others I guess you get to boast a bit.At 556 pages it takes some effort to get through the book but I found it worth the time.

As a professional musician I've been a reader of Rolling Stone since the late 1960s and this behind the scene look at the world of rock music through the experiences of its publisher is nothing short of amazing. From early days in San Fransisco through very recent times, Jann lays out the music scene and its influence on popular culture - and Rolling Stone's place smack in the middle of it all. He and others at the magazine realized early on that they could also be one of the voices of the huge cultural shift in the latter part of the 20th Century and the embraced that role with incisive political reporting, too. Werner is not afraid to catalog both mistakes and triumphs through the years from a deeply personal perspective. Sex, drugs and rock and roll are all here and much more. Although he drops story after story of personal contact with virtually every big name in rock music those stories are told in a matter of fact manner; no hero worship here! He makes no denial of his admiration for certain people in the world of modern American popular music but does a great job of humanizing them with insights about their professional and private personas without value judgements.The book is long and occasionally lags a bit but stick with it if you want to confirm or find out the truth behind the  inexorable ties between modern popular music and the monumental changes in American culture over the last half century. Highly, highly recommended!

I enjoyed reading this book about the bay area scene more than NYC and the musical haunts he visited.  He was well connected either by design or happenstance or both.  It reads almost like a diary with real observations and comments that unfortunately some editors take away from authors.  Some online critics fault Jann's writing but it's ok with me.  He has a voice and it's real, calculating, and strategic and....egoistical.  Some Rolling Stone magazines writers I didn't have on the radar and will be reading some mentioned in the book.  There's a rivalry and taunting between the Stones and Jann and it permeates through the book, same with other British bands. It's nuanced yet palpable.  I think he should write another book with more details and dish on others below the radar but it seems he mingled with those higher in the Rock and Roll food chain.

title: Emotional Inheritance: A Therapist, Her Patients, and the Legacy of Trauma
author: Galit Atlas
reviews: Now I've listened to the audiobook a few more times, and will come back to it again and again.Absolutely fascinating, touching and healing. It’s taken me on journeys, made me ask important questions about my family, and I’m just getting started. It helped me understand and release some pain I was holding inside that wasn’t mine. I’m continuing to learn more - thank you Dr. Atlas for this incredible work that keeps on giving !

TL/DR (side bar: why do people always put those at the bottom; shouldn't they be at the top if you don't want to read the whole thing? I digress): If you liked MAYBE YOU SHOULD TALK TO SOMEONE, you'll like EMOTIONAL INHERITANCE.Both books are written by therapists, both weave the therapist's journey in the book, and both share patient journeys. But EMOTIONAL INHERITANCE focuses on the intergenerational trauma. And let me tell you, for my deep thinkers who love going down a good rabbit hole (hi, it's me), this book is for you. Not everyone will go down hypothetical paths or rabbit holes with me but that's why I hold those friends even nearer and dearer. (LOL) Exploring the intergenerational trauma, the cycles that thread their way through families is just.... so fascinating.The word I keep using to describe this book is *interesting* and while that feels like a bland description, I was SO INTERESTED. As a reader, obviously I love stories and everyone has a story. But then to explore their parents and THEIR stories (and thus, how that affected how they viewed the world, what they taught their children, etc) was so fascinating. And then THEIR parents. This book is split into three sections: grandparents, parents, ourselves. Whew-- it goes deep and I am so here for it.How many times do you hear someone say "that's a generational thing"? It's so true. Generations before us saw some tough stuff. Many of them were taught not to discuss things. Move on. "Get over it." Since children emulate what they see, no wonder things get... complicated through generations.If you're a nonfiction reader, don't miss this one. It's a thought provoking, compelling, quick read about intergenerational trauma and its effects. It's voyeuristic in a self reflective way. Five bright shining stars!

The last chapter of the book is aptly called A Door Opens. That is the most one can expect from reading it: it may unlock a new curiosity or shift the foundation of your mind enough that you want to learn more. It is not a deep account of generational trauma. It does not have a lot of cited research in it. It does not give the reader anything tangible. Rather, it uses narratives, and those narratives may create a curiosity. If you go into it knowing this, I think it can be a good read. It could be good for someone early in their journey of healing their trauma because the stories may be the nudge your subconscious needs to point it in a direction for what to learn about next. And for someone further along the journey, the short stories are definitely interesting and intriguing and perhaps even a welcome change of pace from more academic reads.I did find it hard to not doubt some of the stories a bit. The further I read, the more my spidey senses tingled. It could be purely because it reads like fiction, and that is enough to make me question what's reality. Was the author adjusting the stories to drive a point home? Or did they all pan out this way? There was a perfection to the narratives, of which there are a lot, and an intuitive part of me kept rearing its head. I found this feeling to be distracting toward the end.I think it's also important to note that the author is not without controversy. If people know they had narcissistic parents or BPD parents, one should probably approach with caution. This author is notably known for promoting the idea of family "reunification" - which most modern professionals would agree only works when both parties are willing to be active participants in that process (and can be further traumatizing otherwise).

title: Now Is Not the Time to Panic: A Novel
author: Kevin Wilson
Ginnifer Goodwin
reviews: But as usual, Kevin Wilson presents us with these complicated characters and weaves a beautiful story together that leaves you just a bit unsettled. We are fugitives...
If you like weird teenage protagonists who make art and get into trouble (while also being quite neurotic) this book might be for you.
His best book is the one about the burning children, this was good but not AS good, so 4 out of 5

This is a weird book, and I mean that in the best possible way. I love that the characters are weird and awkward and genuine. For such an odd book, it is written so well that  it seems like it could be real

Art comes in many forms. Whether words or drawings or sculpture, it is one thing that helps us remember the past.  To remember when everything seemed possible.Two lonely, insecure teens meet at the local pool and strike up a friendship. They have several things in common: they both love art (one is a writer, one a drawer), both are awkward and have  few friends. Both teens’ fathers have left their mothers for another woman, they each have struggled with this loss, as have their mothers, both wish that they could do something to get them selves  noticed.Together they decide to create a poster which will remain anonymous, although it will make them famous - if only to one another. They will post it all over town just for the fun of watching people wonder. Things take a turn for the worse when 2 young teens use the poster as an excuse for being home late from a party. Then the poster takes on a life of its own. Is it Satanic? Does it have a secret message? Is it about drugs, violence, sex?This is a unusual, well-written coming-of-age story of two oddball teens who fill their summer days with a unique bonding experience that will forever be their secret and forever be a part of their lives.⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️Author Kevin Wilson tells us that when he was a freshman in college he had a boring job (didn’t we all?)  transferring documents to digital. To spice up his job he would, occasionally, intersperse a random phrase into his document. Be sure to listen to the entire Audio Note from the author.
This is the second book of his I've read, both I enjoyed.  He has a gift of describing outcasts in an empathic way.  Interesting themes on art and how it can be received differently.

This is one of the stories that is so weirdly fantastic that I find it hard to imagine where it came from.  Beautifully written and an excellent story.  Loved it.  Loved the characters.  Thank you Mr. Wilson

I enjoy Mr Wilson's work a lot.  But, for me, this book spent too much time on the early, teenaged years of character.  Of course, the whole poster story was good and essential, but the 2nd part when she looked back at it as an adult interested me more.  I got bored with all the teenaged drama. It might've been better as a novella.

title: Things We Do in the Dark: A Novel
author: Jennifer Hillier
reviews: This book was about a woman named Paris who is found in her husband's bathroom covered in his blood with the murder weapon in hand. It looks bad, sounds bad but did she really kill her husband? The book goes through what really happened and it's very gripping.Possible spoilers....Possible spoilers:...Review: The book was well written. I didn't catch a spelling error or a misplaced sentence. I found it to be very captivating even starting on the very first page. It definitely makes you curious and makes you think and guess what's going to happen. There were twists I didn't see coming (not to sound so cliche but it's true). Its truly a really good book. I was entranced. I honestly wanted to binge it but couldn't since I didn't have the time.I rated it a 4 because although well written and I loved it, some things I had issues with.📍First being: The language that was used that's supposed to Filipino?? I think..it wasnt translatable on my Kindle so I had NO CLUE what was truly said. In some parts, the author did translate some but not all. I felt a little lost and a little stupid. Hated that. 📍 Second being: As a reader, your being flashed back in the past and to the present day without warning. There wasn't a break in chapters or anything to say 10 years ago or five years ago etc. It catches you off guard  📍 Third being: It was said that Charles was unalived with lexi's ice skate. Ruby was to have to put on the skate and unalived Charles. How?? How can a woman in her thirties put on a teenagers ice skate??📍Fourth being: Toward the ending of the book: Zoe asks Elsie why Elsie lied to the police of the last time she shaw Jimmy. Zoe says it was Elsie who disabled the home system and wiped all the data. wait...HOW DID ZOE KNOW ABOUT THE DATA SWEEP? HOW DID ZOE KNOW THE SYSTEM WAS DISABLED?? The only people who knew about the erasing of the data was Elsie, Paris, and the new lawyer.📍 Fifth and last, Elsie said that after she unloved Jimmy with the razor she bleached it and put it back in the drawer.If that's true then how did Paris have it in her hand next to the tub ??? Remember, she was covered in blood and the detective commanded her to drop the weapon???Conclusion: It was a good book. It was enticing and decently written. I Loved it. It just had some issues. And some things didn't add up. That's the only mistake I found. It's a good book though and I'll probably reread it 😊

Things we do in the dark kept my interest from the first scene to the end.The main character is Paris Peralta. She is found by the cops in the bathroom with her husband’s dead body in the tub and she is holding the murder weapon in her hands.Looks bad, right?Worse, her husband Jimmy Peralta is 30 years older than she is. Jimmy is also famous. He was part of a show that everyone remembers and recently he has come back from retirement to do a couple of comedy specials.Paris knows the situation is dire. Yet, it can be worse if they find out the truth of who she really is. Although, someone already knows and is blackmailing her.Ruby Reyes, the Ice Queen, is in prison in Canada. She is about to be released back into society after murdering a man. She knows who Paris is and wants money in exchange for silence.Drew is an investigative reporter in Toronto. His next true-crime podcast is about Ruby Reyes and her daughter. He wants the world to know what an awful person Ruby really is. Drew feels guilty. He made mistakes and he is relieving the time when he let his friend down.Joey Reyes is the daughter of Ruby Reyes. She suffered in the hands of Ruby's verbal and physical abuse.Things we do in the Dark has three POVs. Paris, Drew, and Joey. We get to know Joey and what she went through from early childhood. It was quite heartbreaking.I found the audiobook to be perfect for this novel. It kept the timelines straight for me. I enjoyed all 3 POVs and despite guessing the twists, I found that I liked the overall picture.Cliffhanger: No4/5 Fangs

4 1/2 stars.My first book by Jennifer Hillier was Little Secrets and I loved it. So I was excited for her new book, Things We Do in the Dark, and I am happy to report this book did not disappoint. This book was just as good as the previous book I read.Paris Peralta has been arrested for killing her husband. She was found in their bathroom, covered in blood holding a straight edge razor and her husband was dead in the bathtub behind her. Paris did not kill her husband, but it is not that she has been arrested that worries her, it is the fact that her husband was a famous comedian and his death, and her arrest is going to bring media attention to her, and Paris does not want anyone from her past to recognize her and destroy the new life she has worked hard to build for herself. Twenty-five years ago, Ruby Reyes was convicted of killing her married lover. Ruby knows who Paris is and after being released from prison early, she is threatening to expose Paris. Paris has no choice but to face her dark past.This story is told in a dual timeline. The first timeline is in the present and follows Paris as she tries to clear her name in the death of her husband, as well as trying to keep her past from being exposed. I liked Paris and hoped that she would be able to figure out a way to prove her innocence. I figured out pretty early on what were some of the secrets from her past she was running from. In this timeline we also get the POV of Drew Malcom. Drew is a journalist, who currently has a podcast called “Things We Do in the Dark” and he is currently doing a segment on Ruby Reyes. It is during his research for the podcast that Drew unintentionally uncovers the secrets that Paris is trying to hide.The second timeline was my favorite. This timeline is told from the POV of Ruby Reyes’ daughter Joey and takes place twenty-five years ago. In this timeline we follow Joey before and after her mother was convicted of murder. I loved Joey so much and had such sympathy for her. She had a very hard life. Her mother was abusive to her. She also suffered abuse from her mother’s many boyfriends, and once her mother was in prison and she went to live with her aunt, uncle and cousins, things did not get any better. I had tears in my eyes a few times while reading.There is so much I want to say about this book but cannot without spoiling things. I loved everything about it. Even though I figured out the connection between Paris and Joey, there were still a few twists that caught me off guard. Hillier did an amazing job of bringing this story and the characters to life. I highly recommend Things We Do in the Dark. Be forewarned though, this book is pretty graphic in the blood department, and it does deal with child abuse.

title: Unmasked: My Life Solving America's Cold Cases
author: Paul Holes
Robin Gaby Fisher
reviews: I remember well the day that the Golden State Killer (GSK) was finally unmasked as Joseph James DeAngelo, whom I will simply refer to as JJD from here on for brevity.  My wife and I were having our house painted and I was lying in bed inside, trying to avoid the outside chaos, and also trying to keep from getting any paint on me as well.  I picked up my iPad, looked at the day's news, and then my eyes got big.  No, they got HUGE.  But I jumped out of bed, ran to the front door, opened it, and exclaimed to one of the painters, "Did you hear that the Golden State Killer was just arrested?!"  His reply:  "Who's the Golden State Killer?"I couldn't believe it.I couldn't believe that the GSK was finally caught.  But maybe more incredibly, I couldn't believe that someone didn't know who that was, especially in the area where I live, just above the Napa Valley.  I thought that everyone knew about the Visalia Ransacker (VR) who morphed into the East Area Rapist (EAR) who then became the Original Night Stalker (ONS) whose nickname was finally wrapped up into the Golden State Killer (GSK) by Michelle McNamara.  She was in the middle of writing a book not long before his capture, from memory.  Unfortunately, she didn't live long enough to finish it but lucky for us true-crime aficionados her book "I'll be Gone in the Dark" (IGD) was finalized and published, supposedly by some of her assistants.  And I can attest to the fact that IGD is a very good read as I bought, downloaded, and read it myself.But then again, I've read many books about the GSK.  "Killers Keep Secrets" (KKS) which is an interesting book written (from memory) by the ex-brother-in-law of JJD.  "The Case of the Golden State Killer" (CGSK) which is a slightly unpolished effort but nonetheless informative read about the case where you will learn information probably not found anywhere else.  "Hunting a Psychopath" (HAP) which is an oddly humorous look at the case written by one of the original detectives on the EAR case, Richard Shelby.  I've even taken on a couple others which I found nearly unreadable.  But of course now I've just read "Unmasked:  My Life Solving America's Cold Cases" (UNMASKED) which might be the most interesting of them all, mostly because it is written by the CSI-slash-DNA Expert-slash-detective Paul Holes, maybe the most important person in the case as he finally solved it around 45 years after it all started.  But of course a big assist goes to Barbara Rae-Venter, the genealogist who helped Mr. Holes with research and building family trees for the case.Now, the GSK case isn't the only one included in "Unmasked:  My Life Solving America's Cold Cases" as the title implies.  Mr. Holes returns periodically throughout the book to discuss his progress on the GSK case, intermingled with other cases he worked alongside stories about his own personal life as well.  Some of that life Mr. Holes seems to be very happy about -- investigating and solving cases is his "purpose on Earth" to risk misquoting him -- and some of that life Mr. Holes seems to be not always proud of -- perhaps how chasing serial killers and other bad guys had detrimental effects on his family.And I'm assuming that Mr. Holes has had three of them.  Families, that is.  His original family included his parents and siblings.  Then he was married in his mid-twenties and started having children of his own perhaps before he was really ready, as he even admits.  Then he was divorced and was married again to his second wife and then had a couple more kids.  Mr. Holes has had at least four more children than I have but I still am able to empathize with him as he tells his story about feeling guilt, guilt that maybe he wasn't there enough for those children.  But if you take my strong recommendation to buy and read UNMASKED you can read about that yourself.I just watched an interview this week -- the week of April 28, 2022 -- with Mr. Holes where the interviewer actually brings up the fact that he discusses a lot of his private life in the book.  I would say that usually, most true-crime "fans" -- fans of the genre and not fans of the crimes themselves, of course -- aren't really much interested in "personal stuff."  They want to read about the crime!  And they want to read about how the detectives investigated the crime!  And they want to read about how the UNSUB became the suspect who became the Number One Suspect who became a convict sitting in an 8 x 10 cell so he can realize why committing that crime was such a bad idea in the first place!  That kind of stuff.  But to me I actually like the parts in the book where Mr. Holes discusses his private life.  I was a fan of his television show -- "The DNA of Murder with Paul Holes" -- even though each episode didn't necessarily have a tidy conclusion, and I actually wanted to know more about him, and not just his investigations.  It was just that he seems like a nice guy and so I was interested to learn how he became that nice guy.  It's either that or he does one heck of a job faking it.  But I'm so rarely "accused" of being a nice guy myself I found it interesting to see how someone else can pull it off.  Ahem.In reality this review could become a book in and of itself if I wrote about everything that I liked, disliked, or maybe was simply neutral about.  Instead I'll keep it short and just create a bulleted list of highlights or interesting points, at least for me, in no particular order:1.  I thought it was interesting that Mr. Holes and his family, after he retired, moved to the same town where Joe Kenda had been a detective, and Mr. Kenda had moved out of that same town when he retired. (I guess maybe detectives find it necessary to "Get out of Dodge.")2.  There is a show called "Real Detective" on the Investigation Discovery (ID) Network that I really like.  Season 2, Episode 1, entitled "Blood Brothers" is a must see.  John Conaty, a friend of Mr. Holes, is heavily featured during that episode.  At any rate the story in that episode is included in UNMASKED.3.  I really like the fact that Mr. Holes uses the first-person "I" throughout.  I do it myself in reviews, usually to alert the reader that what I'm writing is my opinion.4.  Believe it or not I got some really good laughs while reading.  One:  "Guns don't kill people, I kill people."  Everything is funny dependent upon context, I suppose.  Two:  "Hurricane Holes."  Supposedly that was Mr. Holes' nickname given to him by his coworkers and I used it for comic relief in the title of this review.5.  The Jaycee Dugard case.  I read her book "A Stolen Life" -- I recommend it -- and I actually once drove past the house in Antioch where she was held for 18 years, mostly out of curiosity.  (I drove past JJD's old house in Citrus Heights once too but THAT story is for another day as it is just too crazy to include here.)Well, if you've ever seen Paul Holes on TV you'll probably think that he at least seems like a nice guy.  And that is true even though his coworkers gave him the nickname "Hurricane Holes."  But how about changing that nickname to "Hilarious Holes" as he does have a way of periodically bringing some humor into an otherwise dark story.  But to finally wrap this up before I overstay my welcome, to Mr. Holes I will write, "Enjoy your retirement!  You deserve it!" although it seems he's working harder nowadays than he ever has, what with his book and television deals alone.  But then I'd add, "Thanks again for catching the Golden State Killer.  Even if that painter guy didn't know who that was."

Paul Holes share a part of his soul in this book. I’ve only recently begun reading true crime but I’ve been listen to Paul Holes for years. If you love the podcasts he been on through the years you really should consider reading this book. If your intrigued by GSK then this book is a must read.

Not the book. Holes is a pretty fair writer and he had a helper. Bummer refers to the reality behind this famously handsome criminalist. When he went public after the capture of the Golden State Killer I actually sent an email cautioning him. I knew he would be inundated with female attention. I thought he should be protective of his marriage. Yes, even his male coworkers from a long time ago nicknamed him, "Handsome ".So, why mention all this? Because it's a stark, strange reality that exists for this man and for people who meet him and know basically nothing about him. Because, you see, behind the fine bone structure hides a haunted mind. Paul Holes is haunted to the point of self medictating with alcohol. He talks about it at length. No secret there.So here you will get fascinating explanations of how science tracked down killers. You will hear about stupid politics at the office. You will hear  about nightmares and panic attacks. About a wallflower personality. About what happens to a person who " compartmentalizes".You will find out that that handsome face hides indescribable horrors.A very good and frightening book.

My favorite read of 2023! Suspense, twists and turns, held me at the edge of my seat until the last chapter. Beautifully written and the vulnerability Hole shares around his work life balance is deeply felt. Would love to read a part 2 from this author!

As a former USAF Special Agent doing criminal interrogations for over twenty five years, this book was difficult for me to put down even at bedtime.  I became immersed Holes' writing and could almost feel his emotions.  This was one great true life crime book.
Very well written and easy to follow.  I heard the audio book wasn’t good so I got the hard back book and read it in a week.

I am halfway through this book and forcing myself to continue because it’s for a book club I want to join, but I absolutely do not understand why people love it. The author seems like a complete jerk. His attempts to justify his poor treatment of his first wife and kids as, “It was for the greater good of society,” fall flat. No, he was fascinated by the work and didn’t really give two rips about anyone else. I find his admissions about how much he ignored them were utterly self-serving. If I cared about anyone in his story, it was his first wife, Lori, whose plaintive, “I just don’t know what you want from me,” broke my heart. She was begging him to just once talk to her. And he just says, “Too late.” She was a way lovelier person than he could ever be, and I hope she is happy in her later marriage.As for the true crime aspect, most of the stories were highly superficial, which caused the reading of this book to be greatly prolonged as I invariably had to google each case to get more than skin deep insight. I’m less interested in the grim details than the motivation of the perpetrator(s) and task force personnel.Frankly, I am unsure why everyone loves this book? The author’s drive to solve the cases seems less to me of an act of compassion as repeated attempts to prove his own self worth when he, deep down, seems like a shallow, self-centered man. Perhaps I am mistaken, but reading this boring book that regurgitates therapy catch phrases about his deteriorated personal life, is at best 3 stars. I have just finished some phenomenal true crime books about Ted Bundy that were FAR superior.

title: Prisoners of the Castle: An Epic Story of Survival and Escape from Colditz, the Nazis' Fortress Prison
author: Ben Macintyre
reviews: Another riveting account of WWII.  This time the men of Colditz, how they survive, how the escape.  Macintyre never fails to bring a story down to the personal within the global context.  Am always sorry when I finish a book of his…..and I’ve read them all…..that I need to wait for the next one.
Book was well written but at times it goes a little overboard with the information. I ended up skipping some pages.

This is an excellent book for facts about officer POWs. I understand it is not great to be imprisoned. Yet, their conditions were far better than those of prisoners held at labor camps. In all my reading of people that hid in fear, worked to death at camps, starved to death, froze to death, these men were mostly bored, uncomfortable, and according to this book spent a lot of time inventing games, playing games, planning escapes, masturbating or turning to homosexuality. I never knew officers were held prisoners away from enlisted men or away from the Jews and other political prisoners.

Every chapter had something new and riveting.  I found myself reading extracts to my wife. The prison housed many who had escaped from other camps, but who were captured. The different nationalities competed to built escape tunnels of their own. This sometimes caused building problems or inadvertently caused the discovery other nationalities tunnels. Many RAF pilots were imprisoned there. Class strictures were maintained amongst the British. Donald Badar, the double amputee,  does not come across as the cheerful chappy as in the movie, Reach for the Sky, but as mean spirited and nasty. Many future dramatists got a start in prison dramatics. the author covers brilliantly a number escapes and attempted escapes. He details the great importance of Red Cross parcels and the trading that went on between prisoners and German guards. The anger and jealousy between ex RAF officers relating to TV program on the Escape from Colditz.  A great read.

Though captured life for officers was gloomy, boring, limited, the unexpected heroic escapes, the creative replacement gadgets, and, the diverse panoply of unique characters, result in an absorbing eloquent kaleidoscope of a WWII prison.  Colditz is an impregnable medieval castle atop a hill detaining high risk Allied officers.  Fascinating fount of detailed information, especially the importance of Red Cross food parcels.  Swiss bureaucrats routinely inspected the POW facility pursuant to the 1929 Geneva Convention which was surprisingly rigorously adhered by the Germans.  Wing Commander Douglas Bader, the notorious double amputee fighter ace, was also an inmate.  Riveting, distressing, astounding -- man's inhumanity.
I found myself getting confused sometimes but overall this is a good historical read. I had never heard of Colditz prison prior to reading this book so it was interesting to me in that regard.

I thought this book was a great read. I learned quite a bit more about World War 2.  Truth is stranger than fiction. Certain parts of the book had me thinking about Hogan's Heroes and the Shawhank Redemption.  It was interesting to read all the background stories of the different prisoners and their determination and ingenuity.

Colditz Castle is an immense fortress in eastern Germany, for centuries a place of both refuge and imprisonment for a wide variety of inhabitants.  During World War II it became a holding pen for the most incorrigible trouble makers  as well as some of the most prominent or well-connected among the Allied prisoners.  Tales of what happened inside Colditz during those years began to spread even before the war ended, and in the eighty years since those stories have assumed the stuff of myths and legends.  Ben Macintyre has written a comprehensive history of the men who spent the war years inside Colditz, both as prisoners and as guards, that makes for an absolutely unput-downable read.When we read spy novels and memoirs or watch James Bond films we often find the tales of incredible escapes, intricate devices, and raw courage almost unbelievable.  Prisoners of the Castle has plenty of such tales that make anything Ian Fleming wrote seem tame in contrast.  As you read, you'll be overawed by the determination and character displayed by men like Airey Neave, Douglas Bader, Birendranath Mazumbar, Florimond Duke,  and Michael Sinclair, among many others.  You'll be just as impressed with many of the German officers like Reinhold Eggers, as well as with the multitude of others from outside Colditz who assisted the captives there, such as Irma Wernicke, Lee Carson, and Jane Walker.I'm always glad to see a new Ben Macintyre book on sale.  He always tells fascinating stories that are meticulously documented, filled with amazing anecdotes and incredible feats.  Prisoners of the Castle is one of his best works, ranking alongside Operation Mincemeat, Agent Zigzag, and Double Cross.  Buy it, but make sure you have plenty of reading time available, because you will not want to put Prisoners of the Castle down.

title: Hello, Molly!: A Memoir
author: Molly Shannon
Sean Wilsey
reviews: Great easy read on her life. Very interesting to get the “inside” scoop on SNL. Comedians are so darn smart!!You’ll love Molly Shannon even more after reading this!
I loved this book- got it for my son who majored in comedic arts and he too thought the book was great

Loved this book it was hilarious! A friend in our book club recommended it at a time when we were all going through a lot. It was a great “pick me up”. Turning a tragic situation into something that’s laughable.
I won't lie that I didn't know much of Molly Shannon other than SNL and Superstar but this book was captivating from start to finish.
Interesting story. Makes me appreciate molly Shannon’s humor even more.

If you have a beating heart in your chest, you will fall in love with Molly Shannon after reading this book. Was a big fan before, now I truly wish she was my BFF.  And Jim Shannon! my heart! What an incredible life. ❤️❤️❤️❤️
I enjoyed this book but it was a little all over the place. You get a good idea of how hard it is to make it in the business .
Couldn’t put it down! You go away wanting to be Molly’s bff! I happened to read this at age 50!!!

title: A Lady's Guide to Fortune-Hunting: A Novel
author: Sophie Irwin
reviews: “I think I am quite a different person, now,” he continued, eyes not leaving hers for a second, “for having met you and . . . I like who I am, who I have become, around you.” ~ Radcliffe ❤️So when I first began reading this novel, I was constantly comparing it to other media such as Bridgerton, on Netflix, because they had such similar plots. But once I stopped looking in that lens, I actually really enjoyed the story.Although I DID in fact enjoy this novel, it was very much predictable, and even when there were attempts at foreshadowing, it all kinda fell flat. I personally prefer more discrete foreshadowing, whereas in this case, it was as if it was slammed down on the page with a giant “LOOK HERE I’M IMPORTANT!” in big red letters. It was never simply implied for the reader to figure out amongst themselves, but stated rather matter-of-factly.All that aside, I would suggest this read to anyone who has that Bridgerton itch they just need to scratch. If you enjoy the regency era with all the splendor and amazement of cotillions and fancy dresses, with a touch of blackmail, this novel by Sophie Irwin is definitely for you.“Yes,” she confessed. “I will always choose my sisters. I will choose their need more than my want every day. But I want you just as much as I need money. You see me, in my entirety—the worst and the best of me—as no one else ever has.” ~ Kitty 💖

A wonderfully fun regency! The storyline is familiar but the story itself is fresh and well written. I love the witty, practical, and determined FMC, who was as honest as she needed to be for herself, was unable to bury her innate kindness, and was determined to live up to her responsibilities to her family.  I also enjoyed the slow burn romance between the main characters. Although it is an excellent first novel, I’m sad that the author does not have a back catalog for me to dive into now.

She might not be Charlotte Lucas in fact but very much her sister in spirit. Jilted and faced with penury Kitty Talbot sets off to London to save her younger sisters by sacrificing herself on the altar of matrimony. She just needs to find the moneyed man first.
Great characters and a modern spin on ballrooms and romances of the past. Kitty is a heroine to admire for her honesty, loyalty and spunk.

Think of this book as something written by Julia Quinn but without the steamy sex scenes. It was well written, true to the period, and had delightfully witty repartee between the characters. The author has cleverly created a family comprised of five sisters, setting herself up for a series. I look forward to the next one.

I picked this up without high expectations, but I have to say that it was refreshing. There wasn't any sex or cursing, no real violence or drugs. It was a really wholesome story at a time when there aren't many of these coming out. I'm not surprised that there is criticism because it's not the typical book being released in modern times. The story is fairly straightforward with some mild humor. It's an antiquated setting with a main character stuck at a time when women had few options. Some readers may hate that she is going to marry someone rich, but that's the main point of the book, after all.

A Lady’s Guide to Fortune Hunting by Sophie Irwin is everything I fell in love with about reading and everything I want in historical romance. The humor is subtle. The dialogue is perfection. The oh-so-familiar storyline is freshly and deftly done.Ms. Irwin is a true ‘teller of tales.’ Her plot never slows and her characters never bore. She did her homework on Regency England, the balls, the gowns, ‘The Season’, and, most importantly, the levels of the societal norms of the times. The heroine who must find and snare a rich husband is anything but a stock character. The hero who sees right through her finds her conniving and distasteful until he sees his world through the lens of her circumstances.This is a story with heart and it stole mine! My only disappointment was knowing this was a debut novel and I can’t immediately dive into another by this author. But her name is on my list and you can be sure I’ll be waiting and watching and ready to click ‘buy now’!

Kitty has been left with a house in debt and three younger sisters, so after losing her fiancee, she decides to go to London to find herself a rich husband to make sure the house stays with her and her sisters. But she finds herself pushing for more, making sure that she finds a husband rich enough to pay off her parent's debts. When she is caught and called out, she blackmails the brother of her potential match to find more matches so that she can have several men to pick from. It raised the question of how women find a way to make their way in that world when you really had no rights. I enjoyed the book and the characters were great, I will be looking to see what Sophia Irwin does next. I would almost like to see more of Kitty and James and their families.

title: How Not to Drown in a Glass of Water: A Novel
author: Angie Cruz
Kimberly M. Wetherell
reviews: with a smile, because you will immediately become the social worker who hears the narrator's stories about her life, as she speaks about the past in the Dominican Republic, the present, unemployed, with benefits, all sorts of issues with the government, the management company, family members, neighbors from the other apartments in her building, which roll out fluently.

The book is structured through interviews between Cara and an interviewer from an employee assistance program as she is forced to navigate the world of unemployment after the factory she worked for shut down. Cara uses this time to give long ramblings and intimate details about her life. She shows incredible life experience and wisdom juxtaposed with an almost naivety about her relationships and situation.This novel is one of my favorite character studies I’ve seen. It is so honest and complex. I felt both irritation and a deep empathy and tenderness towards Cara at times, and she is just a character that will stay with me. I encourage everyone to give this one a try!
I liked the language the Spanish and the English.  Just a beautiful book!  She reminds me of myself in certain ways.

I absolutely love this book, and the author! It is not written in a traditional style, but it absolutely works. Angie Cruz deals with a ton of real-world issues, such as generational trauma, gentrification, and falling into debt, while still providing areas of comic relief. 100% worth a buy!
Angie Cruz nos ha dado un bello ejemplo de cómo sobrevivir. ¡Qué mujer! Quisiera tener la sabiduría y la fortaleza de Cara Romero.

Cara complains about her lack of work, about her ex-husband, her son and that's just the people close to her. But over the subsequent chapter you begin to see the flicker of heartfelt insights dawning on her. You'll be rooting for her the whole way
Cara is a force of nature, and a compelling and entertaining narrator. I loved her story, with all its vibrancy, beauty, pain and triumph. And hey, even Alicia the Psychic wins in the end.

It's a quick read, full of thought provoking stories of a middle aged woman making the best out of being unemployed. Loved the main charachter, she loves her neighbors, community, family! Highly recommend this read!

title: How to Raise an Antiracist
author: Ibram X. Kendi
reviews: Incredibly thoughtful and well written. I think this book focuses on how racism is created and affects our children and what we can do to actively combat racism. He has many important studies woven in with historical understanding. The one thing I did wish, was that there were more specifics on how to discuss with your child.
This is a must read for all caregivers. Ibram X. Kendi is brilliant. Great read on an important topic.
A gift for a new baby’s parents. Education starts at home.
I love to read books where I can walk away with some personal growth—How to Raise an Antiracist was 100% such a book for me.

Excellent complement to How to Be an Antiracist.  How to be an Antiracist is a thought-provoking, insightful guide on raising your children to be antiracist.  I wish this had existed when my kids were young.  A must-read for all parents.

A thoughtful guide on modeling conversations about race and racism for young kids, in recognition of the fact that they will be exposed to a lot of prejudiced situations and ideas that can be internalized if not actively confronted. This book definitely builds on author Ibram X. Kendi's previous works like Stamped from the Beginning or especially How to Be an Antiracist, suggesting a framework in which individual actions either uphold or oppose bigotry -- with neutrality always defaulting to the former in a bigoted society like ours -- but I think it would still succeed for readers entering the curriculum here. (My advice for parents/caregivers might even be to start with this title, and only backtrack to those others if you find yourself resisting or confused by the writer's definitions and assertions.)Some of the material can be a bit off-topic. The medical racism experienced by Kendi's wife during her first pregnancy, for instance, although harrowing and illustrative of a widespread problem driving Black maternal mortality rates, doesn't have much to do with raising children in an antiracist mindset. And there are a lot of passages that might be better suited for memoir, given how they reflect on moments in the author's childhood when adults did not push back on racism that he was encountering then. But generally speaking, this is a valuable text for prompting proactive household discussions, featuring plenty of real-life examples to draw on and illustrating why a so-called "colorblind" approach of ignoring race and other human differences tends to reinforce bias rather than diminish it.[Content warning for gun violence, lynching, and racial slurs.]

How to Raise an Antiracist by Ibram X. Kendi is both an intensely personal memoir and a throughly researched explanation about the societal harms of racism and the importance of teaching antiracist values and actions to our children. Kendi’s writing is clear and compassionate and designed to leave parents, teachers, and caregivers feeling empowered and hopeful about their ability to engage in antiracist practices and teachings for the next generation.

How to Raise an Antiracist by Ibram X Kendi is a valuable book for anyone even remotely involved in a child's life. The lessons here will have as much impact on the adults as on the children.I am in complete agreement with the idea that everyone is, in practice, either racist or antiracist. In other words, if all one says is "I am not racist," even if they mean it, but does little to nothing to combat racism, then they are a de facto racist. If you don't speak up when a friend says or does something, you are encouraging further racism, thus, in action, you are a racist, even if you disagree with what they said or did. One doesn't define oneself by a negation, being "not a racist" might be descriptive but not much more. In a society in which race is built into so many aspects, one is either antiracist or, whether through inaction or actual intent, racist. That said, even someone who is antiracist can do or say racist things. The difference is usually one of awareness. An antiracist is less concerned with defending oneself than with improving, while the racist (including the "I'm not racist" variety) tries to rationalize or defend. We all have moments where we contribute to the racism in our society, to pretend otherwise is dangerous. It is what we choose to do when we realize what we are doing that makes a difference, both in ourselves and our society.All of that is to say that I found this book valuable in not just how I (should have) raised my children but also in how I can contribute to how others raise their children. The children in extended families and in communities are raised by everyone there, like it or not. We can make it easier on parents if we are also modeling antiracist behavior. Ideally we do so all the time no matter who is around, but we can make a point of being particularly vigilant when young people are around.If you're worried about being preached to in this book, don't be. Kendi passionately makes his points but does so as often by showing his own mistakes as pointing out the mistakes of others. The personal thread that runs throughout the book makes it almost memoirish at the same time that it allows the reader to feel less guilt about the mistakes in our past. We make mistakes, we can learn from them and improve or dwell on rationalizing them and contribute to racism. That choice is on you.I would highly recommend this to not only parents but anyone even remotely involved with young people.Reviewed from a copy made available by the publisher via NetGalley.

title: Bad City: Peril and Power in the City of Angels
author: Paul Pringle
reviews: This book is fast paced and gives you a lot of info. The corruption it uncovers seems to have been in place a long time, and the longer it went on the more people were involved. Some of them didn't even profit from it, they just went along because they were told to. Pringle wrote a very enjoyable book and I would like to read more of his work.
Yet when I read the front page headlines of the LA Times, their political slant is as obvious as ever.
