It’s rare that I can’t put a book down — especially a non-fiction one.  The bravest of all in this story is Paul Pringle who never let the notion “the truth hurts” stop him from telling it.

This book and is an incredible and shocking expose' of what went on behind the scenes in the medical department at University of Southern California (USC).  Author Paul Pringle, an investigative reporter at the L.A. Times, bravely pushed forward to make this information public despite enormous push-back from his employer, the Times.  Nothing stopped him from revealing the truth.  I strongly suspect that there are some in administration at USC who harbor an intense hatred for Mr. Pringle.
The book was excellent.
I learned a lot about the Los Angeles Times, investigative reporting and what was happening behind the scenes of some big headlines.  I’m glad I read it!
very good book

You will be outraged with every page you turn in this book about corruption, addiction, depravity and deception and the widespread coverup they created in Los Angeles. Los Angeles Times investigative reporter Paul Pringle shows just how hard it is to root out the truth in his compelling, detailed and suspenseful account of wrongdoing at the highest levels of some of the loftiest institutions in Los Angeles, including his employer. The book reveals his reporting methodology and the many obstacles he faced during a difficult investigation into USC that ultimately also absorbed the LA Times and police departments from Pasadena to Huntington Beach. The engaging chapters show how he revealed multiple scandals at the University of Southern California. First, he documented the misdeeds of former USC School of Medicine Dean Carmen Puliafito and his despicable, sick need to control  vulnerable young people with drugs and money. Further, Pringle and other LAT reporters uncovered the decades-long sexual abuse by USC gynecologist George Tyndall, and later, the bribe-for-admission operation dubbed Varsity Blues. USC paid $1 BILLION in damages for Tyndall, and the admissions scandal brought shame to USC and wealthy parents with unexceptional children. Read this book, subscribe to reputable newspapers and take home the lessons of the story: The truth matters.

title: Shutter
author: Ramona Emerson
Charley Flyte
reviews: I enjoyed reading this book but at the same time I was disappointed. On one hand there was a good story here. The author does a nice job at keeping you engaged. The downfall was that the synopsis of the book didn't really match up with what was in the book. It sounds like this is going to be a crazy ride with ghosts and killer cartel groups. It is, but most of that doesn't happen until the end of the book. You have the nagging ghost but for most of the story, you learn about Rita and her family, flashing back to the past then coming into the present. Like I said, this was nicely done but not what I was wanting. Hopefully if Rita's story continues, we'll get more action and less backstory since we know all about her now.

I hope she continues with this character.  The writing will become more polished over time.I would hope that there would be more Navajo cultural inclusion in the future.  I served in the IHS on the Navajo many years ago, and can't forget how much that experience has ment to me ever since.

For a debut novel, this was fantastic! I absolutely loved this story and the characters, alive and dead! It's got everything I like in a novel; a mystery, paranormal phenomenon and Native American culture all wrapped up in one! I am so looking forward to a sequel and I hope it's soon Ms. Emerson!! Thank you for sharing your book!!

I found the novel, “Shutter,” by Ramona Emerson quite entertaining.  It was a unique story of young Navajo lady who is a police photographer in Albuquerque, New Mexico.  She has the unusual talent being able to see and converse with dead people.  The plot was sometimes a bit thin and events a bit too conveniently connected at times but, even so, I enjoyed the story.  Not too deep, but a fun read.
Interesting premise with interesting characters.  The plot was ok, but repetitive in spots.  I enjoyed the descriptions of the scenery.

New author to me. Didn't have a clue about the plot or characters beforehand.  Unbelievably, six of my undergrad  elective classes were in forensic sciences, photography, and Native  American culture and religious .  Public healthcare was the focus of my life for  25 years. I couldn't put this book aside willingly.  Have collected the Hillermans, Coel,Doss, Johnson,JAJance, Thurlos, Stabenow, and more. I will now be adding Ramona Emerson ...bolo...

The novel, “Shutter” by Ramona Emerson, captured my interest from the first paragraph. The main character, Rita, of Navajo background, is a forensic photographer for the Albuquerque police department. Rita has another unique talent: she can see and communicate with the spirits of deceased people, be they friends or relatives, if they died naturally, in a car accident, or were killed violently. This ability has been both a blessing and a curse, mainly the latter. The story is told through the use of present time in one chapter, and the past in the next chapter. In the story, she is pursued by the ghosts of people who are seeking justice for being murdered. Most of the novel takes place in Albuquerque, Gallup, Tohatchie (a town on the Navajo reservation), and other towns in New Mexico; living in New Mexico, I certainly enjoyed reading about places I’m (somewhat) familiar with. I also enjoyed reading about aspects of Native and Hispanic culture, and how some elders from both the Native culture and Hispanic culture came together to pray in their respective ways to save the life of Rita when she was in danger. I also enjoyed the photography aspect: each chapter was given a title that referenced a particular camera, or a camera setting, and even computers. I truly enjoyed this novel.
Love the fact that it starts out graphic details, doesn't let up. Hard to put down.

title: Book Lovers
author: Emily Henry
reviews: "Maybe love shouldn't be built on a foundation of compromises, but maybe it can't exist without them either.Not the kind that forces two people into shapes they don't fit in, but the kind that loosens their grips, always leaves room to grow.Compromises that say, there will be a you-shaped space in my heart, and if your shape changes, I will adaptNo matter where we go, our love will stretch out to hold us, and that makes me feel like...like everything will be okay"I don't even know where to start with this book! but let me just say two things-1)I bow to the queen of witty and captivating contemporary romance books, I will read your grocery list, your 3yr old to-do list or a detailed recipe on how to broil Asparagus to perfection.I will read anything and everything you shall write.2)Emily Henry's books are truly soul food, they penetrate deep inside your skin and settle down in your soulALL THE STARS IN THE SKY!_________________________________Book Lovers is one of my most anticipated releases this year, after being moved by Beach Read and how PWMOV spoke to me, I thought I am ready for her new book, ehh naah I wasn’t prepared for the onslaught-she blew it out of the park once again with this charming blue book which is filled with larger than life emotions. Emily Henry has the knack to cater a book for a wide set of audience but somehow can make it personal to each and everyone of her readers, I believe everyone has something or the other within themselves that they can relate to her books with.Book Lovers felt like a witty, heartfelt love letter to life filled with hard to talk about emotions, day to day relationship struggles, familial bonds and deeply rooted anxiety that can stem out of loss and grief. There were moments I laughed so much that my insides were in stitches and then there were endearing moments that made me heart ache with joy, this once again is a very quotable book like her other books.It follows Nora, a literary agent who is a city girl through and through and holds life by it reigns trying to have everything under control. Nora's character is a personification of a strong woman who wants everything and has the capability to take it,but what lies under that brave facade goes deeper than she could ever anticipate, her life revolves around her younger sister Libby to whom she is more of a mother than a sister. Nora's fear of losing makes her overprotective at times so when Libby and Nora feel like they are drifting apart, they decide to go on a vacation to spend time together, a lot of things boils to the surface during their time in a small quaint town in North Carolina, which Nora will have to tackle head on. Nora's character will be quite relatable to people who have hard time sorting their emotions and talking about them, I absolutely adored her character growthNora and Libby's struggles and sibling rivalry is true to real life and complex because of the way they grew up and varying perspectives they have on life, I love how their relationship wasn't turned into something hurtful or ugly. It was authentic and refreshing how their characters develop and how their love for each other changes them into better people, if you have a sister yourself I dare you not to cry while you read their beautiful relationshipThe unexpected twist Nora's doesn't anticipate while going on this "trip of a lifetime" is having to see the ever charming albeit snarky Charlie Lastra, her work nemesis which later ensues a fiery banter and sizzling chemistry between these two true enemies.Nora and Charlie's banter is a chef's kiss, they have so many witty word volley's that will make you guffaw and make you forget that you are reading, my heart is so full while I read the precious moments between them.I also had to say this is probably the "spiciest" of all Emily Henry books could go on spice level with few open door scenes. Here is one of my favorite quote-"Be my shark Stephens". "Already was",I say. "Always have been"."I love you", he says again."I love you too". I don't have to force it past a knot or through the vise of a tight throat.Its simply the truth, and it breathes out of me, a wisp of smoke, a sigh, another floating blossom on a current carrying billions of them."I know",he says. "I can read you like a book".What to expect-Heartfelt belly laughs as a result of witty/hilarious writing-A story of two siblings that tugs at your heart strings-A strong woman's love letter to life in NYC- Endearing moments that will make your soul content-A beautiful love story between two characters who can be easily misunderstood- Deep discussions on big foot erotica ;)Do yourself a favor and get lost in this book!PS- That epilogue tho…TW- Anxiety, Death of a parent, grief

It has been awhile since a book moved me so completely that I was unable to find words to express myself, and instead, I just cracked open  and spilled tears all over my Kindle! Wow! Book Lovers by Emily Henry is that kind of a book. I was enthralled and catapulted from my reality into the world of Ms. Henry's creation.This is the first book I have read of Emily Henry; I am not sure if my heart can take reading any others! I struggle to find the words that would explain the impact this book had on me. I found Nora and Charlie to be strangely relatable characters though they are different from me as night and day. Career driven, big city-lovers, should have nothing in common with an  old retired RN, who comfortably  settled in rural Missouri.  And yet, I was struck by how whole passages that Emily Henry penned were exactly what I would have said, if I could have found the words to put my thoughts into clear sentences. "Killing me softly with his song...telling my whole life with his words..." It was incredible, and terrifying at the same time.I can see why Book Lovers was on the Amazon Best of 2022 list. I can see why it was an editors pick. From page  one to the very last word I was spirited away from my real life and thrust into the world that Ms. Henry had created.  As Nora pointed out in this story, some books you don't read, you live them, and that was certainly my reaction to Book Lovers. There are many parts of this book I have highlighted for future review. There are sentences and phrases I will go back and chew on, savoring the flavors and tastes that Emily's clever word choices bring to mind. This is a book that I will bring out and read again and again, whenever I struggle to find the words I need to express my thoughts  aloud to someone! A classic of the time, Book Lovers is a book even those who hate romance genre will want to read.

This was my first Emily Henry book, and I will definitely be reading more of her novels! Book Lovers was an incredibly witty and sweet rom-com with a new take on some classic romance tropes.Nora Stephens is a New York literary agent who some call a “shark,” but really she’s just great at her job, works hard, and cares about her clients. Charlie Lastra is a New York editor who previously turned down Nora’s top client’s last novel. The two start as enemies, and since I love the enemies-to-lovers trope, this was perfect for me!Much of the book takes place in the somewhat idyllic/somewhat campy Sunshine Falls, North Carolina. I like that this setting was made to be beautiful but also at times slightly depressing, with a fun cast of characters and their quirky businesses.Although Nora and Charlie’s romance is unique, sweet, and slow-burny, with sooo much witty banter, my favorite relationship in this story was that of Nora and her younger sister Libby. The two experienced a major tragedy when they were a young adult and a teenager, and Nora has been trying to take care of Libby ever since (even though Libby is married and has two daughters with another on the way). This puts a strain on their relationship, especially when Nora seemingly puts her job before everything else. This story is all about how the two sisters come back together, share their secrets with each other, and discover an even tighter bond than the one they had when they were younger.If you want to grin, cry a little, laugh out loud, and be amazed by Ms. Henry’s cultural references (especially of the book variety), I highly recommend you read Book Lovers!

title: The Last Slave Ship: The True Story of How Clotilda Was Found, Her Descendants, and an Extraordinary Reckoning
author: Ben Raines
reviews: This book is a must read for every American who values history, but reads like a swashbuckling pirates adventure.  I couldn’t put it down and have bought copies for friends too. I have lived in Mobile Alabama for more than 30 years.  When people mentioned Africatown, I would protest, thinking they were disparaging a black community north of downtown that was surrounded by heavy industry. I was astounded that a group of Africans who were brought here on a bet by a wealthy steamboat captain long after the importation of slaves had been outlawed had indeed formed the community and called it Africatown.  Ben has painstakingly researched the captains logs and historical documents to reconstruct the story. He went to Benin, Africa to see for himself where those people had been captured and sold. Then he searched the muddy delta and discovered the remains of the Clotilda, the last slave ship, that had been burned and sunk to hide evidence of the crime.Read and enjoy the story. You may be moved to come visit the “best new museum of 2023” to open later this year in Africatown, Mobile, Alabama.

In many ways, this book is amazing.  We get the background of Clotilda, the last slave ship to bring people from Africa for the purpose of enslavement in the US.  We read about the raid in Africa that captured the people, their journey across the Atlantic, and their life once in Alabama.  We see the establishment of their community post-Civil War and the growth of that community, along with following the people who came over on Clotilda.  The narrative continues with the development and eventual decay of Africa Town.  There’s discussion of how the actual shipwreck was discovered and the current state of affairs in the area of Africa where one of the major ports of the slave trade was.  The history is fascinating. I was drawn in emotionally.  The reason for 4 stars rather than 5 is that I struggled with the inclusion of some of the information (too much? relevance?) and I felt the flow of the narrative wasn’t smooth.

I am truly  sorry this happened so many years ago. I believe history needs to be taught in school as it happened. I received the white washed view. So reading this book for the Kindle challenge was definitely an eye opener. There were so many facts I wasn't taught in school or by anyone else. The writing was hard for me to get through because its history. I would read a chapter then switch to another book, usually horror, my usual reading style. The book is well written. Thank you for writing. I found it hard to read because of subject content. Thank you for teaching me the correct history.

I had heard of the Clotilda, but not the story of the captives who were sold into slavery, brought to the US and after the Civil War established Africatown and made a new lives for themselves in the United States, governing themselves and raising their families.  There was so much that I did not know about their experiences.  It was an informative book, and a touching one.  I highly recommend it.

This book is a must-read for any American. There is pain, anger, heartache, laughter, and tears. I am from a small rural mountain region in upstate NY. The swamps and bayous of the area around Mobile is as foreign to me as Africa, herself. I am grateful to the author for opening this window into America's past and present - and maybe, hope for reconciliation in the future.
Easy read. This book reads more like a novel. Peaked my interest in the subject.

This book is a must read for all students of African American history and everyone interested in the passage of African slaves and their final voyage to the America.  Only by reading this book, we can fully understand the role  of the Africans and the Slave transporters  and traders played in this human tragedy of America's slave past.  This book illustrate the need for this story to required reading for all.
Cohesive depiction of the struggle to find the Clotilde slave ship.

title: In Love: A Memoir of Love and Loss
author: Amy Bloom
reviews: "In Love: A Memoir of Love and Loss" by Amy Bloom tells the story of a couple who, when the husband develops Alzheimer's Disease, seek physician-assisted suicide to end his suffering. With this topic, many people feel strongly enough about the issue to say, "No thanks," but Bloom gives us details that activate your empathy as you know Bloom's anguish.Bloom provides a glimpse of the human experience that has a lot in common with regular, old-fashioned grief. You try to soak in the last moments and want your loved one around for selfish reasons, even though they no longer wish to suffer. The more I read the author in pain, the less my politics interfered or mattered.Alzheimer's Disease has touched our lives in some form or another. Bloom reads directly from some of the manuals for caregivers to show precisely how different her reality is from those who try to oversimplify for support. For this reason, it baffles me that anyone would find a flaw in the book since, if anything, it made me value my time on this Earth more and reminded me why I would make a different choice in this situation but still understand Amy's plight.Your feelings about this will coincide with your initial reaction to the end of "Million Dollar Baby" for reasons that would spoil a 19-year-old movie for some but will paint an all-too-familiar portrait of emotional trauma. Only the heartless would judge. Every decision at the end of the book causes stress, from the mundane to life and death. The scene at the casino shows how tough it is to rein in a patient with dementia when others encourage you to let them live.The journey to the end of the book is long and painful, but then again, so is Alzheimer's. The text may not dispel your opinions, but it will show you that no one can or will enter this decision lightly or quickly. The cost eliminates 75% of the world's population anyway. So accept this writing as one of the most human experiences you will read about this year.

This book is beautiful, sad, strong, and absolutely worth the read. I work in Hospice and support MAiD, Medical Aid in Dying, so this story was highly interesting to me. I am grateful to learn from honest, open experiences people go through and still find the strength to share with us. I took my time reading this one as I wanted to absorb it all. I needed tissues a few times. I smiled, laughed, felt their hope, frustration, exhaustion; but it was worth every minute. Thank You, Amy, for sharing Brian and your story with us.
I cried through the last few chapters even though there were no surprises. It’s beautifully written and important. I love Brian and Amy.
This book is inspirational as well as informational. It's so poigant. It makes you think about all you have and what you can loose without any real warning. I cried.

Honest and moving story of the biggest of love and sacrifices we can make for each other - the being there no matter what. It hits close to home in some ways and it is now under my skin. But I love this book completely
A profoundly beautiful book on life, love and choosing how to die. I loved am inspired by the grace, love, courage and humor shared in this short gem.
This book moved me so. I took breaks from it, as it felt like a journey with close friends. Just wonderful!

For those all too close to Alzheimer’s Disease, both those who have it and the ones who love them, this book provides an alternative to the long Goodbye.  Written with honesty and love, it is a brave, realistic and loving pathway.  I laughed and I cried as the author shares their journey.

title: Butts: A Backstory
author: Heather Radke
reviews: funny serious book about gehinds

This book weaves together history, pop culture, and intersectional studies in a brilliant and entertaining way. How beauty standards are established and by whom is fascinating and enlightening. Really well done.

This is a in-depth look and personal reflection of our relationship with butts. I liked that it explores our historical as well as current perspective on the butt, but adds a personality to the narrative that makes for a fun read. I gave this as a gift and kept one for myself.

Really enjoyed the balance between research and current cultural relevance. If you like the Malcolm Gladwell/Mary Roach approach which blends journalistic writing with humor and approachability you’ll enjoy this book. It’s a good book to grab for a vacation where you can read in bits or plow through on an international flight!

Other reviewers found humor in this book, but it is grim political cant.The book stars well, describing how human bipedal movement differs from quadrupeds.  From that point forward, the book degenerates to recounting exploitation, appropriation, popular culture, and social media trends.Every human has a butt, and butts are secondary sexual characteristics.  It would have been refreshing to read about what makes a butt attractive to the opposite sex, and if this is consistent outside the US and UK.  Alas, that has to be found elsewhere.The Kindle version has no table of contents.
Nothing sexy about this book……major disappointment.
Cover was dirty and slightly damaged

This was an incredibly fun non-fiction to read, the perfect book to carry around in your bag. It's a conversation starter, a laugh-out-loud-on-the-train commute/waiting room/airplane/sit-by-the-pool-and-watch-butts-walk-by kind of read. I thoroughly enjoyed it on multiple levels.First, on content: Radke's research is well done. This is not an academic, peer reviewed piece of scholarship, but it is a well-researched, chronological and multi-disciplinary perspective on that part of our body we might often despise/regret/wish hidden/love/extoll/exhibit. Butts begins with an evolutionary explanation, a physiological treatise in what, why, and how we have butts at all and what they do for us. It then moves on into history proper, working to the present, and ending with a significant number of chapters focused on butts in the contemporary moment (Kim Kardashian and others) and in popular Western culture. [Radke is up front with the Western-centric focus of her study; this is a commentary on butts as understood in Western culture and history and is not a global study.]Second, prose: Radke's delivery is on point for a non-academic, general audience non-fiction. The prose is smooth, hilarious in so many parts, and remains lighthearted throughout, even when the content gets heavy and educational.Whatever you feelings and thoughts about butts, backsides, or bottoms, Butts is a great read.

title: The Come Up: An Oral History of the Rise of Hip-Hop
author: Jonathan Abrams
reviews: another banger from Jon A.

Essential reading for all hip hop fans, no matter when you started listening. Everyone gets a full experience. For me it was a mix of reminiscing and learning a lot of new names and events I didn’t know about. You can’t help but have a deeper appreciation for hip hop at the end. The pictures bring it to life, too. So glad this history is captured, especially in the words of the creators themselves.

Packed with first-person accounts of the rise of Hip Hop from those who kicked it off. Much like Jim Fricke’s and Charlie Ahearn’s Yes, Yes, Y’all, but less visually appealing as it’s hundreds of pages of text formatted monotonously, without pictures to break up the uniformity, until the end. (C’mon, publishers. Get some graphic designers in on these projects.)I’ll echo the comment of another viewer requesting a playlist. Saw the Selected Bibliography, but who needs to read more after this? Haha. I want music.

A walk down memory lane. Johnathan Abrams takes us all the way back to the birth of hip-hop. And it was a reminder for me, if some great times and lots of fun. As he went through the growing years, mentioning crews and songs, memories came flooding back to me. This is a definitive chronicle of the building of what we know now as hip-hop culture. Johnathan Abrams seemingly spoke with everyone who was someone bringing this book alive. Hearing from some of hip-hop’s luminaries as they don the 20-20 lens of hindsight fills in some of the mysterious holes. You know, those rumors you heard about rapper X, but never could quite confirm. Some of those underground stories are brought to surface here.Thanks to the Crown publishing group and Netgalley for an advanced digital copy.

How does an artistic movement begin. One person with an idea, a group of like minded people trying to entertain their friends, family, and others. People hopping on an idea to get them out of a place they know will probably keep them down or even kill them. Or as one person says in this book and I am paraphrasing, your brain is not the same as my brain, and we are not the same brain as this other guy, so what we can do with beats and samples will be totally different. That sounds as good a reason as any. The history of hip-hop has tons of stories about talent, musical and lyrical skills, breaks, helping some, dissing others, and a lot of using brains. Jonathan Abrams author and journalist has done his best to bring all their stories back to us in The Come Up: An Oral History of the Rise of Hip-Hop, in which players discuss the game from its beginnings up to the present day.The book covers over fifty year of history, starting in the block parties of New York City, expanding to the West Coast, and back to New York. Miami and the South are discussed as is the Mid-West. The book is a chronological history, but does move around a bit to get a sense of the scene and the people involved. The interviews share a theme discussing the ideas behind the block parties, the rise of the DJ and the scene, finding the beats to get the party started, and keep the people moving. The coming of MCs to hype up the people, evolving into rhymes and rhythms that started to get socially aware, as well as body moving. Disco influences, drum machines, West Coast sound, horror core, drill, trap. All with historical asides to tie-in events and movements that keep the narrative moving.The book is worth the hype. Most of my knowledge of hip-hop is of a person living in Connecticut watching on MTV and even I was amazed at what I remembered. The interviews are very good, informative, and when a story goes one way, Abrams finds another person, to go, hmm no this is what really happened. There are so many good stories, of people so just loving the music and getting behind it, helping each other out, sharing beats, rhymes, studio time, and supporting each other. Reading this one is amazed at how many lives were changed by hip-hop, some for good, but for others tragically. Abrams keeps the narrative going and describes, even to a neophyte like myself, the different sounds of different areas, and never loses track, or bogs down. With so large a cast that he interviewed I can't imagine that was easy, and I am quite impressed by all his work and how he arranged it. My favorite chapters are near the end, where the questions are more about creativity. People discussing filling journals with lines, or others just thinking about it in traffic, laying it down in the studio. Or just blasting back in rap battles right off the cuff. For so much talk about the evils of hip-hop that this kind of skill is just amazing to even think about, and I am in awe at their abilities on the mike, on the turntables, or in producing these songs.A book that needs a playlist. Readers will be on Spotify or checking out vinyl racks to see what secrets might be in their collections. This book is not just a history but a celebration of an American made form of music that could only have been created at a certain time, under certain conditions. Highly recommended for music fans, and cultural studies fans. This is a book that others will be compared to.
This was a phenomenal look at the origins of hip hop told by those who created it. It’s a massive book, but well worth the time it will take to read.

title: Raising Lazarus: Hope, Justice, and the Future of America's Overdose Crisis
author: Beth Macy
reviews: Ms. Macy gets it. We all (yes, YOU too!), have a role to play in addressing this crisis of addiction in America. Whether you have the ability to read this book and pass along what you've read and learned, or perhaps you have some pull in your community- and can help barrier change policies or funding streams that allow for equitable access to care and treatment, maybe set up transportation volunteers to get folks to court or treatment. Maybe you work directly with individuals with substance use disorder and can help train staff and your community on cultural humility around SUD and how to reduce stigma and create safe space. This book provide examples of real life helpers who are walking in their callings to serve those society has deemed unworthy, unlovable, and untouchable.We all can do something to help. I hope this book inspires you to explore your options and turn them into action. Acta Non Verba!

A great follow up to Dopesick. Certainly a convincing case for harm reduction. As a healthcare worker, I was slightly irked by the authors treatment of those dealing with addiction on the front lines, specifically ER employees. To be described they way they are without the attention to what impact the opioid epidemic has had on them is a glaring ommison. The author advocates for unconditional compassion for those with SUD, but does not extend that some courtesy to those who are involved in the daily struggle of dealing with those in the throes of addiction who frequently perpetuate the verbal and physical abuse of healthcare employees who do not feed their addiction when they demand it.

The media could not be loaded.
                



 Based on my experience and expectations I was so pleased  with the book and  her work and research on Addiction in this Country . I got a chance to hear her speak in Baltimore! She is a Shero of mine.

Tess Henry said that while she was slowly losing her battle to addiction. Beth Macy chronicles some steps that have occurred since, that Tess could only dream about. This book provides a roadmap to what needs to be done and will help make Tess’s dream a reality one day BUT we’re not there yet!  Interwoven with the frontline hero stories she takes you behind the scenes of the Purdue Pharma bankruptcy SCAM.
Great follow-up to Dopesick and tells the real stories of real people fighting from all angles!
Exciting, great read , powerful

Beth Macy spent 332 pages blaming everyone but the addicts for their lot in life.  Not surprisingly, she puts most of the post-Perdue blame on conservatives while lecturing that harm reduction, not personal accountability, is the only way to fix this situation.  I felt like I was sitting in the principal’s office getting scolded for something I didn’t do.  It’s not her fault as she did what her and everyone else in the mainstream, corporate media does best: project blame onto others.  Don’t waste your time on this book.  Fentanyl, Inc is a far better book that offers a much more subjective look at opioid problem.
A look at people on the front lines dealing with those addicted to opioids.  This book  gave me nightmares  but was a fascinating read.

title: The Man Who Could Move Clouds: A Memoir
author: Ingrid Rojas Contreras
reviews: First I have to say the pictures of her mother shows her alluring beauty. It would have been nice to have met her. The book had some wonderful stories. It gave me an understanding as to why I talk to my memories. Enjoyable.
With beautiful poetic prose, the author paints a picture of the world her family inhabits, grounded in her indigenous roots and full of the wonder of life and death.

Provides insights into indigenous ways, indigenous history, much South American history. Provides glimpses of what it’s like to experience amnesia and how that experience can alter your experience of the world. Touches on ways living with ongoing war and guerilla warfare manifest in our bodies.
Astonishing crack of light into a cloudy history, told in a prose that haunts and delights!  How to see into your past. . .

THE MAN WHO COULD MOVE CLOUDS is a remarkable memoir filled with mysticism and magic. It is a glimpse into cultural beliefs and mythology at once foreign to most Americans and yet, oddly comforting and reassuring. Highly recommended.
I got about half way through the book and could not finish it.Should have been a lot shorter.

One of the best books I’ve read in a while. A beautiful, magical family memoir traced over three generations. Violence, change, suffering, and memory take center stage and are handled wonderfully in their interactions. Highly recommend.

I did not know what to expect from this story. When it arrived, I could not recall why I had chosen to read it. I am pleasantly surprised and thrilled to have added it to my "to read" list.I love the feeling of reading a fantastical tale that I labeled in the genre of Garcia Marquez only to read from the author that it's "realism." What a concept, I thought, to be reminded that different perspectives and definition if what is real and what is allegory.While I did not have the same experience as the author, I too grew up as a woman from a Spanish colonized country. I can relate. But I do want to elaborate how I relate other than finding a connection with her.This book will stay with me.

title: Corrections in Ink: A Memoir
author: Keri Blakinger
reviews: This isn't usually the type of book I read, but my interest in keeping a wide variety of styles combined with the topic made me pick it up - and while some of the earlier childhood chapters drag a bit, the entire story of how the author fell into addiction, crawled through prison, and came out the other side to acknowledge her privilege and use that experience to help others on the inside is often heartbreaking but always fascinating.  Easy to read, easy to recommend.  I hope she continues her work.

I just finished Blakinger’s masterpiece.  And before life swept me along to my next mission, I stopped to write this review.  Keri Blakinger’s account of her descent into darkness and her rise out of it has left me with a cacophony of emotions that will take some time to sort out. I spent 2020 walking the deserted streets of Midtown Manhattan handing out sandwiches to the homeless people n our neighborhood.  I listened as they told me their stories.  What had led them to their fates.  All but one of the fifty men and women my husband and I befriended had spent time in prison. All were addicts.  I vaguely knew that prison was not a nice place to be.  And I knew the stories of some of the homeless women we met. What they had to do in prison. But I never “felt” the reality of what prison can do to a person until I read Keri’s book.  Bravo, Keri.  For your courage.  For your honesty.  For your strength of character.  And especially for the hope that you give to all of us.  Even in the midst of darkness, there is always a glimmer of hope.TMR, Wall Street Journal and USA Today bestselling author.

I read this book just after reading the Myth of Normal, which talks extensively about addiction being a coping mechanism for trauma. As I read about all the incarcerated women and the struggles they faced, that was all I could think about. These are traumatized women who never received the help and support they needed, and their lives spiraled a result. And of course, incarceration only adds to the trauma. The authors ability to overcome the challenges she faced is admirable, as is her ability to speak plainly and truthfully about the challenges she faced, and to acknowledge the privileges that nonetheless smoothed the path for her. Her work to bring to light the grave injustices of incarceration, and to aid those still inside, is inspiring. Highly recommend.
I love this book. It tells a great story and is very interesting all and out.

keri takes you on an immersive journey through skating & addiction & prison with a cunning self awareness clearly shaped by an abundance of time to reflect in prison. i love the tales of the people she meets along the way as well. highly recommend

Inspiring work that hits on all cylinders.  It’s so profound and moving that when I finished I cried.  Happy she had done something this meaningful, sad the book was over and hurt we as humans do this to each other.
I enjoyed this. It was entertaining, and inspiring. never boring. Love to see the full arc of the authors journey from childhood through adolescnents and finally througout her recovery.

Keri told her story in ways that made me cringe , but that’s why it was so hard to stop reading. This is a powerful story of her life : skating career, eating disorders, anxiety and drug addiction that lead to incarceration . I’m so happy she was able to stay sober and turn her life around.

title: The Kaiju Preservation Society
author: John Scalzi
Wil Wheaton
Audible Studios
reviews: This book succeeds at being exactly what the author set out for it to be:  a light, fluffy novel to enjoy after a particularly stressful time in our recent history.  It works gloriously -- I had a blast reading this.  That said, I'll agree with some of the observations of other reviewers that Jamie's (he's the viewpoint character) friends are not particularly developed.  But I think that is fine, because the whole purpose of a book like this is just to take the reader on a fun ride without getting overly bogged down in things like character development.  This book is the written equivalent of a fun adventure movie (and, in fact, I think it would adapt well to the screen), as opposed to the sort of deeply introspective things that win awards.So, a little background.  This novel starts at the beginning of the Covid pandemic in 2020 and is set during the pandemic and the 2020 presidential election.  In fact, it ends right after the election.  And while those things don't dominate this book, they are an important aspect to the context of the novel -- because part of the fun of this book is the idea of being able to just disappear into another world for a few months and not have to deal with those things.  But without the pandemic, Jamie likely never would have even been in a position where he'd have been offered a job with the Kaiju Preservation Society.Aside from that, the premise is that the Kaiju (Japanese movie monsters) are real and that they exist on a parallel Earth.  The Kaiju Preservation Society sends people to this alternate Earth where they both study and care for these creatures.  And therein lies some of the appeal of the book and why the pandemic and presidential election matter to the success of this book.  After all, what science fiction reader doesn't find the idea of having spent 2020 in an alternate world more than a bit appealing?  I don't want to do any spoilers, so I'll just note that while the first half of the book is primarily setting things up, there is some genuine action and adventure in the second half.The only other thing I'll note is that if you're one of those people who think that "woke" is awful and Trump is a great president, I suggest that you skip this book.  You won't like it -- it contains a non-binary character and the author's political leanings will annoy you -- and you'll come back and unfairly malign this book.  But for anyone else who enjoys science fiction and/or movie monsters, it's well worth reading.

In his afterword, John Scalzi says of The Kaiju Preservation Society that "it is not...a brooding symphony of a novel. It's a pop song. It's meant to be light and catchy, with three minutes of hooks and choruses for you to sing along with, and then you're done and you go on with your day, hopefully with a smile on your face." That's a pretty accurate description of KPS, which is an enormously entertaining, if slight, book about a government agency that oversees, studies, and yes, preserves a planet full of kaiju - massive monsters a la Godzilla, Mothra, and the like. (Kaiju is the Japanese name for the giant monster genre.) Told in Scalzi's usual jokey, quippy style, KPS moves rapidly, delivers some amazing wonder, gives enough plot to get the job done, and moves on - much like the pop song he concedes the book to be. That's both to its credit - the book is hugely fun, harbors no illusions about what it is, and delivers the entertainment is wants to do - and its detriment, as the villain is a bit heavy-handed, the plot a little obvious and unsurprising, and the world ultimately less explored than I wish it was. But as Scalzi says, "we all need a pop song from time to time," and he's not wrong - KPS was exactly what I needed after a few heavier books and some general stress in life. I maybe wish there was a little more heft to it, but as a fun bit of imaginative storytelling, it hit the spot nicely.
There is a movie in this book. Tie it in with the Cloverfield movie and bam, sci- fi fun.

A standalone science fiction book, no prequel or sequel that I know of.  I read the well printed and well bound trade paperback published by Tor in 2023.  The hardback was published in 2022.  I am hoping that there will be sequels.Jamie Gray needed a new job after being fired by his boss, the CEO at füdmüd in New York City as the Covid-19 pandemic was starting.  So, he took the offered job of being a food deliverator for füdmüd out of desperation.  And months later, Jamie met an old acquaintance deliverating food to him, Tom.  Tom ends up offering Jamie a real job working with KPS, an animal rights organization.  The job is six months on site at a incredibly remote location working with very large animals.A fully mature Kaiju is 100 meters to 150 meters (300 feet to 450 feet) tall.  They have parasites inhabiting them that are incredibly dangerous and help them to live.  And, they violate the Square Cube Law with their power source.  And, they can fly.

I like Scalzi stories and this is a good one spawned by COVID quarantine fantasies.  The premises of this novel are unabashedly drawn from other stories, movies and sci-fi dogma and I loved it. Great fun.  Just what I needed getting over the flu.

My heading sums it up. This is my 4th or 5th book ive read by scalvi. He’s funny. His books flow. He doesn’t take stuff too seriously. He writes a good story. You looking for  solid easy sci-fi beach read? Stop and just read this.

I thoroughly enjoyed this novel as a nice break between some more serious reading. I was entertained throughout and appreciate the world Scalzi paints describing how we and Kaiju might live together. This fits in nicely between hard and soft Sci fi genres to give the reader enough of a feel that the science has been thought out without beating them over the head.

After reading the description of this book I was hesitant to buy it.  But then I said to myself - this is a John Scalzi book.  So yeah, I bought it.  It is well-written as expected and held my interest throughout.  I especially liked the beginning which details how Jaime Gray lost his job during the Covid crisis and ended up working for the Kaiju Preservation Society.It is sort of a gritty feel-good book and decidedly a fun read.  Nonetheless I felt a bit disappointed because it lacked the scope and grandeur of his other books such as the Interdependency trilogy and the Old Man's War series.

title: Gilded Mountain: A Novel
author: Kate Manning
reviews: Pleasant read. The author described the hardships of all the characters so realistically…..I just had to keep reading. I couldn’t wait to find out how the main character survived.

Gilded Mountain is a fun and fascinating historical novel about Colorado, mining, small town journalism, the labor movement, life as a young woman in the west in 1907-8, with a view into the high life of prosperous owners of the mine as well as the desperate poverty among those working the mine. The writing is very fine, the research behind the book is thorough whilst never heavy or tedious, and the story is inspirational. You’ll be gripped as you read, and if you share the novel with friends you’ll have so much to talk about and mull over.

In each year there are a few books which are 5 star great and then there are a mere handful which are so exquisite in language and point of view that one wishes they could be awarded 10 stars to reflect that rarefied firmament they occupy.  This is such a book.  From the first sentences to the last there is a masterful hand at the helm, rich sensuous language embellishing vivid characters living a life unknown to us in such a way that our imagination is awakened even as we learn about subjects beyond our ken.  Mineworkers and the violent path toward unionization is brought to life, so too the fallible and human missteps in the storm of lives bending to comprehend and survive struggle.  This is a book to be relished rather than merely devoured.  Highly recommend.

I loved this book. The language is rich and the imagery cinematic. I look forward to the movie I would expect this to become. The protagonist is likable and modest and conflicted. If you are in the mood for classic literature, this is it!

I am an author and reader, and the novel sets a new standard. The writing style carried me back to the early days of Marble and Redstone and brought me even closer to where I live. The narrative is beautiful and profound. Sometimes it feels like the main character is a 21st-century woman dressed in Victorian clothes, but the story is much better for it. This is an epic novel that all should enjoy.

Told with deep love for the people who have worked the mines, with insights into their dangerous live. Loved learning about the West, workers’ strikes in response to exploitation and Mother Jones from a plucky girl reporter from an immigrant family.

This author paints a vivid picture of labor's struggle withthe owners of business in the tradition of Upton Sinclair.The protagonist, Sylvie, is the daughter of a french laborerwho attempts to organize the workers in a marble quarryin Colorado in the early 1900s . The characters are welldrawn and unforgettable.
I could not put this book down.  The tension throughout was perfect. I really appreciated the fact that she was writing of her past in a way only someone that has experienced life totally can do.

title: Our Crooked Hearts: A Novel
author: Melissa Albert
reviews: I didn’t want the story to end. I was right there along with the covenant of witches, brewing a cauldron full of rabbits, blood, and craft. It was excellent!!!!. I did have an initial issue with the author's voice at first. The writing was gritty, and at times I was like, ‘what do you mean by that? is this English’? - The references were very urbanly specific. I didn't get the lingo. But I soon forgot about it and was swept along the spine-chilling plot. The characters too were beautiful and rich, the sweet little romance and the family dynamics were fresh and realistic. I loved the book so much I had to re-read the Hazel Wood, just to get another fix!!! I think Melissa Albert is exceptionally gifted at creating plot, atmosphere and captivating gritty characters - they were all gritty by the way…all had dirty hair and ate with their fingers and cursed…But hey...It was fine. I went along. 4.5 stars for this! And can’t wait for the next book

I loved the Hazel Wood series so much that this is the first book I've preordered. Great story, complex and shady characters. Will buy anything that Melissa Albert writes, I'm a huge fan and I look forward to her next work.

I really enjoyed this novel. I wasn't sure what Melissa Albert was going to come up with after the wonderful Hazelwood series, and I was almost nervous about this new stand-alone novel.I shouldn't have been. It has her wonderful style and voice, and I slid easily into the story. I found even the side characters to be wonderfully rounded and complete. I like how the book was told across multiple time-lines, introducing you a little bit at a time to what you need to know in order to full experience the story. The mother-daughter relationship is marvelously drawn, and the more you understand about each character, the more you sympathize with both of them. Mysteries are drawn out in delicate layers so the whole novel is kind of filled with "aha" moments which raise more questions.I found this to be much more complex than the Hazelwood series, which is excellent. Even though the entwining stories are told from the perspective of young women, it doesn't feel very young-adultish.I thoroughly enjoyed the novel and look forward to her next.

I couldn’t put this book down. The characters practically jump off of the page with their 3-dimensionality. It’s got a carefully constructed narrative conflict central to the story, which is told within a structure that sees the characters through beautifully. Fantastic read!

The prose in this book hits you square in the chest, every time, leaving you breathless and understood.The story is neatly paced and brilliant executed.Reading this book was like having the meal you’ve been craving for months and it’s even better than you remember it.

Wow. I devoured this book in about a day and a half. I loved The Hazel Wood, and I think I loved this book even more! Witchcraft, mothers and daughters, Chicago in the 90s, present-day mystery. This is one of those books that you want to start rereading as soon as you finish it.The book moved back and forth between the now and the then, building the story and layering everything together. The ending was satisfying, and the whole way there was just so engaging. I really liked Ivy, too.
Melissa Albert again succeeds at creating an intoxicating story, ingeniously weaving mother and daughter timelines into a breathtaking, surprisingly inventive plot.

I don't know whether to thank Mimi or yell at her. I literally cannot read Our Crooked Hearts for more than an hour. It is so rich with detail and implication, so full of wonder and fear, so intense a read that I have to come up for air. I have only read one other book like this, and that was The Hazel Wood. Hearts  makes that one look like a trip to the (occult) store. Thank you Melissa Albert!

title: How to Speak Whale: A Voyage into the Future of Animal Communication
author: Tom Mustill
reviews: I can't stop thinking and talking about this book since I read it right after it was released since it fundamentally changed how I think about animal intelligence. Tom does a great job of covering the science but also including memorable stories that bring to life the insights, like how generations of people hunted with orcas (killer whales) and how humpback whale songs get spread across the globe each year.  I eagerly await the day that can communicate better with other species.  I recommend everyone read the book and then watch some excellent footage of whales to complement it (I found a great series on Disney+).
Full of fascinating insights into other mammals and what actually constitutes language. Full of philosophical, scientific and moral arguments. Excellent food for thought.

The most important, and human, question we ask ourselves is, “are we alone?”. Normally that question makes us think of connecting with aliens in space, but in doing so we forget the aliens all around us — animals, especially whales.This book goes on a quest to understand the whales — their biology, their intellect, and their communication, even their culture. We learn about the advances we’ve made in interpreting the vocalizations of whales.The result is unexpectedly moving and profound. This book is a great read, especially paired with Ted Chiang’s short story “The Great Silence”.
This book—beautifully reported and fascinating—will make you want to head to the sea immediately, to commune with its majesty. Hats off to Mustill.

What an adventure! Mustill uses an almost Hitchcockian narration – he starts by describing a near-death experience during whale-watching and then takes a reader on a mindblowing journey, both in geographic and intellectual terms. His curiosity, fueled by this unforgettable encounter, drives him to fascinating places and meetings with extraordinary people. While this is mainly a popular science book, it also blends in travelog, nature, and even tech writing. The first-person perspective works perfectly, engaging the reader, and the style is fresh and witty.I first read about this book in a New Yorker piece by Elizabeth Kolbert, in which she also wrote about the latest Ed Yong book, An Immense World – and I think that if you like both of those authors, you will love “How to Speak Whale” as well.Thanks to the publisher, Grand Central Publishing, and NetGalley for an advanced copy of this book.

title: Tanqueray
author: Brandon Stanton
Stephanie Johnson
reviews: New York night life, so much character - Stephanie’s life is an amazing story! Every page keeps you wanting more. The only downside is I wish it was longer.
Love this collaboration with the author of  Humans of New York.  Fascinating recap of a very interesting lady in NYC in the 60’s and 70’s.  Wishing Tanqueray much health and joy!

Everyone has stories of their lives; some folks tell it better than others.  Tanqueray/Stephanie tells the story of her life well.  Bright moments in the sun shading to cover a lifetime of sorrow and striving to survive.

I'm a HONY regular, so I was quite captivated by this lady's story. So much so, I kept saying after they did the 32part series on HONY, that seriously, Sister needed her own book.  Well, for awhile we didn't hear much, but once Brandon put the word out that a book was coming, we were like seriously waiting on this. I'm not surprised it's a bestseller. I'm also convinced that there's a couple more books in Tanqueray. I'm hoping. But I am glad she's getting her day in the sun because she so richly deserves it. Now, onto the story. She was born in Albany. She and Mom didn't get along, who had a job as an Assistant for the Governor of New York himself. She got pregnant young and was promised a marriage, but dude was already married. so she figures to go back and get her clothes at her moms, she doesnt go through the front door, but gets in, gets busted by dear old Mom, who called 5-0 on her. She had a choice of jail or Mom. Would ya believe, she chose jail. After doing her time,( even though her mom screws the head of the parole board to keep her in, though the warden gave him the slip,she ended up in NYC and became one of the top burlesque girls in Manhattan during the 60s and 70s. She does some name dropping but refuses to divulge the name of the President who came to NYC to be with one of her friends from time to time. She also has a talent for sewing, so sister kept that up. Highly recommend the book but I also advise, she got colorful language, so don't come if that's not your cup of tea. Also check out the words on the front cover. I have since bought the book for a friend on her birthday. We'll see how that go. More more more 9/19/22. Critique. I've been looking forward to MS Tanq's book. and it didn't take long for me to read it. I read it within a setting. I expected more more more, but I get it, you don't mind attention, but not all. I hope she gets a sequel or at least her Tanqueray Tattletales column..
I loved it. Read it in a weekend. Tanqueray is amazing.

I first ready Tanqueray's story on Facebook's Humans of New York thread.  She is quite the character and I loved this book as I got to know her more.  She doesn't hold back on anything - reading this story you understand how much she went through during the years to become the person she is and there are no apologies - she is who she is and that's what makes us love her!

Loved this book!!!! Stephanie is a HOOT! 😂 Could not put this book down and finished it in a day. Highly recommend if you are looking for  Entertainment, NYC History and laughs. Thankful for Brandon Stanton interviewing her, she has stories for days.

I absolutely loved this book from beginning to end. I feel like I could sit and listen to Stephanie's stories all day. I felt like I was right there with her through everything. She is an amazing storyteller.

title: Like, Comment, Subscribe: Inside YouTube's Chaotic Rise to World Domination
author: Mark Bergen
reviews: Most detailed history of YouTube to date. First third was fascinating recount of early days, acquisition, and figuring out what the heck YouTube even was.The back half was fairly repetitive and jumped around to fit a seemingly preconceived opinion on the platform. Wish the author had taken a bit more of a historical/anthropological approach to writing versus political.Felt like there about 25% of the book that could have stopped rinse and repeat same themes to cover others that felt missing (ie product/strategy development like YouTube for TV that got fly-by stats/sentences)

When I pre-ordered this book, I expected it to be well-written and highly informative, but I didn't know what style it would be written in. When it finally arrive, I was pleased to find that "Like, Comment, Subscribe" is an absolute page-turner.This book is not simply a recounting of historical events. It provides an extremely powerful and informed perspective into how YouTube and, by extension, all of social media, is influencing people to act in bizarre and sometimes very sinister ways. I thought I mostly understood the negative impacts that social media is having on society, but this book revealed how much more there is to the story than most realize - or, at least, than I realized.Strong recommend.

By the time you put this book down, you'll be wanting to revisit all your favorite YouTube hits—with new knowledge of what went on "behind-the-scenes" 😀.This is not another boring and anesthetized founder-approved puff piece. It's a thoughtful, detailed look into how YouTube's executives, frontline employees, and creators all contributed to the company's meteoric success, and its sometimes troubling impact on us all.It's also more history book than how-to, so if you're looking for a guide to Silicon Valley hustle culture, then probably best to look elsewhere.There are some poignant moments—I won't forget the story about a moderator having to choose between following company policy or sending a grieving father deleted videos of his son—and many hilarious ones (I mean, it's YouTube!)Ultimately, this book opened my eyes. Knowing how the company mishandled so many opportunities to improve its business makes me question why we aren't giving YouTube just as much scrutiny as Facebook and Twitter.

Bergen's book is nothing short of a masterpiece in storytelling and reporting. He filled in some of my gaps over the company's evolution. His is an insightful and fascinating synthesis and analysis of the über-influential media property, and his writing is top-notch.

As someone who worked with many people in the book and lived through many experiences personally, I was amazed by how much I learned about the inner workings of YouTube. Anyone even remotely interested in YouTube or the creator economy should read this for the foundational insights you won’t find anywhere else.

I've always been interested in the story of Youtube, especially because I grew up up in the Silicon Valley. I think it is one of the most important companies ever created and now we have the definitive book on the company! The book is well-researched, thorough, and extremely insightful.
Mark Bergen has done a brilliant job of de-complexifying a very complex subject. Carefully researched and well written from start to finish with insights from a wide variety of sources. Bravo!!!

Bergen collects quite a few YouTube anecdotes, and displays them in mostly chronological order. I learned a great deal I didn't know before, especially about the economics of social media. But I still don't get any strong sense of who the people are who created the company, what really makes them tick, and why YouTube can't be replaced or dethroned.Bergen's political POV is centrist Democrat. As I read several chapters dealing with topics like Trump, alt-right, DMCA, and sexual videos,  I realized that this is the only way you can get away with writing nonfiction these days. The Overton window is narrow, and getting narrower.

title: Acceptance: A Memoir
author: Emi Nietfeld
reviews: This is a must read. Very inspirational story of resilience and never giving up on your dreams. It will have you in tears at times and most people would have given up but Emi stays in the fight to the end! Amazing! You gotta read this book…loved it

I knew the first time I read a review of this book, before it was released, that I needed to read it. Nietfeld is a talented writer with an endless history of heartbreak, impossible circumstances, and a bottomless well of resilience. Her story isn’t done and her work on acceptance will be ongoing, but she has a wisdom and an understanding of herself that will serve her well. There were moments when I struggled to believe this was all real, but that’s a form of self-protection. Her story isn’t at all typical, from beginning to end, but details aside, her ability to survive is an important thing to know. Things that shatter you don’t always have the last word. Her relationship with her mother broke my heart. Through very different circumstances, I have an understanding of that unnatural rift and the pain it imprints on you. But she shows the importance of choosing what will help you survive, even if it goes against everything you know.

What I love about memoirs is not just the "what happened" but the "how" and the "why," the accumulation of actions, reactions, and emotional machinations that get a person from one place to another. In "Acceptance" Emi Nietfeld describes her difficult childhood in psych wards, in foster care, sleeping in her car, and on other people's couches. Her mother was a hoarder and there was literally not enough room for Nietfled to sleep in the house. Throughout it all, Nietfeld clung to her dreams of going to college. Her studies pulled her forward and she ended up getting an "acceptance" to Harvard.This memoir really got me thinking about love despite dysfunction and/or dysfunction despite love. Her relationship with both her mother and father was complicated to say the least. We see Nietfeld's inner strength, her work ethic, and her missteps, as well. We are reminded in these pages that acceptance is a multifaceted concept involving both forces outside ourselves and forces from within. This story is riveting, painful, and inspiring. I highly recommend.

This is a raw, honest, and hard-hitting memoir about what it means to be up against forces beyond one's control, especially as a young person living in a world governed by messy, contradictory adults. Nietfeld is adroit at capturing her early rage at the challenges she faced living with a hoarder mother who sought to "fix" things by seeking psychiatric help for her daughter and then later denying the seriousness of the abuses that daughter experienced within the foster care system and beyond. The memoir's structure felt as complex as Nietfeld's life, giving us both a wider view of that life while homing in on specific sections of it to explore them in detail, a structure that I thought did the subject matter justice. The memoir gripped me throughout with Nietfeld's direct voice and compelling narrative. As an educator myself, I especially appreciated how well it captured the anxiety felt by many high school seniors, who so often feel as though they must figure out their entire lives at the age of eighteen, yet another absurd demand we place on our young people. This memoir is a truly incredible testament to what it means to try to survive in a world that applauds our survival while simultaneously making that survival feel impossible.
So much to say about this book.  The system is broken and I agree with everything that Emiwrote about.  Very well written.

There’s a sub-genre of memoirs, increasingly common, about people with limited means and lifetimes of trauma making it to college. Far too often a simplistic, grit-focused rags to riches story is told, one that doesn’t challenge the American Dream nonsense at all and just makes the middle class reader feel… satisfied.This is not that book. It may feel like it is at first- the opening pages of this book aren’t nearly as good as those at the end. But Emi is offering angles and nuanced and insights entirely her own- and she’s clearly done the work to understand her life and then observe it from afar.  The result is an engrossing and powerful book that I hope every high school and college student will read- especially those who think highly rejective colleges are the end all be all. Or who think that college is an escape from family and the only key to freedom.I’m truly grateful for this book. I’ll never forget it.

Emi and I actually grew up in the same church, and although I was several years older and didn't know her well, I always wondered what happened to her over the years. When I found out she had written a memoir, I instantly put myself on the wait-list to purchase the book. Reading "Acceptance" instantly brought back the memories I had of Emi over the years, and I wished I would have gotten to know her better and supported her in more ways. It's a great reminder that so many families hide what's truly going on at home, and many children are in so much pain. This book is raw and real, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a true story of resilience and overcoming and the odds.
Really enjoyed this read. I sometime wondered what the point was while reading…however I walked away with greater compassion for people whose lived experience differs from my own.

title: The Hookup Plan
author: Farrah Rochon
reviews: I was highly anticipating London's story in this series. I certainly was not disappointed. London and Drew were high school classmates and she didn't get along with him during that time. They meet up again after 15 years at their class reunion and end up having a one night stand or so they thought. Since Drew is doing a job for the hospital that London works at, he is sticking around for a while. Despite London saying it's a one time thing, they can't keep their hands to themselves. I really enjoyed how Ms. Rochon told this story. I loved how London was able to discover who she truly is and learn to accept love from Drew. This is a true enemies to lovers story which ended up being a soul-searching romance for both Drew and London. I highly recommend this book and suggest that you pick up a copy of this book.

I loved this story. It was very cute, had an interesting story and some mild spice.The perfect beach/summer read. Definitely something I’d want to read again. Drew is perfection and I love everything about his character. I wouldn’t necessarily categorize the story as enemy to lovers (it depends on how enemy-ish you like your enemies to be). More like rivals to lovers. None of the less, loved their relationship and banter from start to finish.

London and Drew's story was the perfect way to close this trilogy. The author, Farrah Rochon, touched on several important elements like disrespectful treatment of wo.en in the work place and society, lack of proper self-care and low self-esteem, disfunctional family relationships, as well as inadequate funding for health facilities in low income neighborhoods and rural communities. This book brought so many emotions to the surface, causing me to reevaluate how I view my time the people I allow into my head/ hart space. It would be nice to get a short book showing where each of these ladies and their men are 5 years from now.

I am amazed by this trilogy let me just Tell you......This friendship these women developed for each other is what this girl inspires to have in life....and the romance was absolutely phenomenal in alk three..... Now about this particular story, everything about it screamed HEEEEEEECCCCK( good word) Yeaaah!!!!.....I have to agree with many others and say LONDON'S story was my favorite! The enemies to lovers troupe never gets old to me, and MS. Rochon didn't disappoint with this one. The struggle that London faced within herself instead if with Drew was on point. And I love how the major "conflict",  if you will, wasn't so much between the two main characters, but with their lives and the people in it......There love story was about as sweet , real, and honest as it gets...and I was here for it!!! Drew wore London down so effortlessly, and London fell so hard before she ever realized what was happening to her! Another 5-star in my book.....I read this in Kindle, but something tells me I need to acquire my own personal physical copy to re-read when the power is out and the cloud is messing up!!! Lolol

The final book in The Boyfriend Project is a winner.  It started slow for me, London was so antagonistic towards Drew I couldn’t see how that would change. Farrah does an excellent job of turning things around for me. London and Drew were able to move past old rivalries to find their HEA.

London Kelly may be still a resident, but she's already made a name for herself as a top doctor, a pediatric surgeon. Her life seems to be going well until she runs into her high school nemesis, Drew Sullivan, at their high school reunion. After 15 years, she is still sore at having to share the valedictorian slot with him. And does he have to be so hot and so successful?A one-time bootie call turns farce as she finds to her dismay that Drew is in charge of the audit of the hospital she works for, an audit which will determine if the hospital should be sold or not.  If there had been residual tension from high school, it ratchets up a few notches from this.  She's understandably angry, feeling betrayed, and yet still attracted to him.  She is also dealing with family issues and trying to decide her career path as she is being courted by other hospitals for fellowships at the close of her residency.London is the last of the three friends in The Boyfriend Project to get her own story and match.  She is brilliant and sassy and caring and I was pleased to see her find a man who is her equal.  They spar like classic lovers: Benedict and Beatrice, Bogie and Bacall, etc. This is a feel-good story with strong, smart, sexy characters that you can't help rooting for. Give a cheer for The Hookup Plan!
This was my favorite book out of the trilogy.  It was the most relatable and was funny and well written.  Love the enemies to lovers troupe.

This book was definitely my favorite out of the collection!! I love how much I could relate to all the characters in each book, but I related to London the most! This was definitely was one of my top 5 books this year!

title: The Unsinkable Greta James: A Novel
author: Jennifer E. Smith
reviews: I loved this book about the life of Greta James, a guitarist, who had life struggles mostly with her Dad. The unexpected death of her Mom who was her biggest fan brought Greta to her knees at a concert that put her career on hold. During this time, she decides to go on an Alaskan cruise that her Mom had booked for her 40th wedding anniversary before she died. Greta didn't want her Dad and four of his friends to go without a partner so she went. This trip was the healing Greta and her Dad needed to get over their grief and the battle they always had over Greta's career choice. She also meets Ben who is separated from his wife and two children. When a medical emergency happens with one of his daughters, he leaves the cruise early to go back to his family. They remain distant friends and the way the book ends, there is hope that they might meet again. I highly recommend this book for those who enjoy books about overcoming life struggles. I am glad I bought this book when it was recommended as one of the top 100 Amazon editor's picks for 2022 books.

A book about life- making choices and living with them.Greta recently lost her mom and is now going on an Alaskan cruise with her dad.  Each moment we have we can either embrace and live it to the fullest or just watch things go by.  Heartfelt story.

Ultimately, I did like this book. The complicated feelings I have ended with me enjoying it, so I’m giving it 4 stars. But there were moments where it was touch and go.First, the rift between Greta and her dad is 100% his fault and the hurt feelings he gets are because he deserved them. Just because his wife died doesn’t mean he suddenly wasn’t awful for 20 years to his daughter. Don’t try to make it about both of them being wrong.Second, the love interest is a famous author who wrote a fictional biography of Jack London (because Hemingway would have been too on the nose) and I swear for a guy so excited about research, he seems to have only scanned Wikipedia in his knowledge of the actual Jack London. He makes bad dad jokes and legit carries an emergency copy of Call of the Wild, so I didn’t completely hate him, but again, it was touch and go.And the end of it all, it didn’t really matter. It made me feel things, I cried. It was stupid. And it didn’t betray its heroine the way I thought it would, so that’s something.

It was so amazing to go on an Alaskan Cruise without having to leave the house. The characters and situation were complicated. One wished for the typical happy ending but one had to be satisfied with the author's realistic conclusion.

These characters will worm their way into your heart!  Families, dealing with hard choices, reality of life/death and past assumptions.  Each person compliments the other, gathering pieces of the other.  Revisiting relationships , conversations and moving forward!
My 2nd favorite genre, real life stories with happy endings that do not shy away from addressing real live people, with real life problems and issues. Feel good book! 5 stars.
Loved the book. 8 days of angst,music, joy , forgiveness and love. Take a chance. It’s really a satisfying read.

I adored this story - as someone who’s lost a parent (and a sibling), the themes in this book hit home for me. Greta and her father’s raw emotions were so familiar to me - so authentic.Not to mention the Jack London tie in - that connected me to this story on a more personal level.A heartwarming story reminding you to really live, not merely exist. Go out there and do what you love.

title: Lavender House: A Novel
author: Lev AC Rosen
reviews: I thoroughly enjoyed reading this story. The main characters had a wonderful decency that you began to see as the story unfolded. Our "hero" detective has the skills to do the job, but he begins to understand how he has not really been a hero to the people that should and, as he realizes throughout the storyline, do matter to him. Any stereotyped characters were, unfortunately, not really stereotypes at all. CIS bullies are still too prevalent today. The plot moved along nicely.  The steps to the murder solution built well upon each other. The more I read, the more I appreciated the humanity and grace of the Lavender House family. This would be a good book for a book club, there are many avenues of discussion...the definition of family, how history has treated gay & lesbians, how literature has portrayed them, how we treat/appreciate the people in our lives, and if you are comfortable with the actions of Pearl at the end of the story.  And I really liked the ending.

Lavender House was one of my favorite books of 2022. The story was complex and the characters were complicated. The story has characteristics of class Noirs like Raymond Chandler or Dashiell Hammett. Take one man down on his luck. He is so down that his next planned step is off the Golden Gate Bridge. Put that man is a house with astounding characters, each with their own agenda, where one of them is a murderer. A house that is far removed from any neighbors. Stir in a little corporate rivalry. Now that man needs to solve the murder against the wishes of a few of the characters. He also needs to stay alive.Vikas Adam's narration was marvelous. In fact, I bought the audiobook of The Far Pavilions simply because he was narrating it. The voice of the main character is rough and his emotions come through clearly. The other members of the household, whether male or female, young or old, are all very well done.I was quickly immersed in the story. The mystery was fun to try to solve. I did not. Lavender House left me wanting more, especially from the main character Andy. The 1950s time period with a queer private detective written by Lev AC Rosen would be an automatic buy.​I received a copy of the audiobook from Netgalley and then won one from Macmillian Audio through an Instagram post. I listened to the audiobook multiple times and wrote an honest review.
While I am not a fan of mystery, I did enjoy the subtle twists of this story.  The only drawback was the formulated structure that reminded me of other whodunits.

The story starts off a hard boiled detective tale with a queer twist, but doesn’t convincingly mimic the tone or voice. The characters are fairly good and engaging but lack depth.
