The predictable mystery is solved as the most likely villain is in fact guilty with nary a twist or turn. The writer is a decent craftsman but some how doesn’t bring this to life.

I enjoyed this book! Interesting characters and good plot, with some deeper meaning set in a historical setting with LGBTQ characters and storyline. I think it would be an excellent start to a detective series… I hope there are more!

I love good, escapism romances, detective novels or any combination thereof. This one manages to weave some (a lot?) of the classic tropes of detective mysteries with a keen sense for the harmful power of marginalization (particularly through homophobia) and the countering, affirmative power of community and agency.

Engaging whodunnit that kept me turning the pages.  I identified with the portrayal of gay life in San Francisco the 1950s, and how awful it was.  I was born in England in 1960 and it wasn’t much better for me growing up; I recently married my husband which was quite some progress!
A gay, disgraced police inspector in early 1950s San Francisco. Homophobia rampant. An evocative tale of exposure and redemption. A thoughtful and compelling novel.

title: His Name Is George Floyd: One Man's Life and the Struggle for Racial Justice
author: Robert Samuels
Toluse Olorunnipa
reviews: George Floyd’s story is a tragedy, and his death has become iconic, a marker of our times. In an age of limitless videos, the images of his final moments have been seen by millions.The book by Robert Samuels and Toluse Olorunnipa is a complete account of Floyd’s life and how he met his untimely end. The title, “His Name is George Floyd”, is taken from the chant activists shouted in the massive protests following his death. Subtitled “One Man’s Life and The Struggle for Racial Justice”, the book is much more than a biography.The first words in the book are “I love you”, a phrase Floyd often spoke before parting from family or friends. Floyd was a loving person throughout his life and when confined along with millions by the Covid lockdown, he made frequent calls to connect with those close to him. Expressions of love continued to the very end of his life where “Floyd repeatedly found his dreams diminished, deferred, and derailed – in no small part because of the color of his skin.”This is the premise of the book, that being Black was the main determinant in Floyd’s life. Guided by this theme, the authors tell of Floyd’s forty-six years leading up to the “nine minutes and 29 seconds he spent gasping for air”, as he died and of the “historic movement for civil rights that followed.”The authors’ stated hope was to put Floyd in context with his world, “never absolving him of responsibility or making excuses for his actions.” This is key because on his final day Floyd was “smoking weed, snorting powdered fentanyl and taking Tylenol.” The book covers at length the external forces affecting Floyd, from the legacy of slavery to his life as a Black man in America.The book is comprehensive, giving the history of racial disparities in both Houston, where Floyd grew up, and of Minneapolis, where he died. The authors delve into the ancestry of major players, especially contrasting Floyd’s roots with those of Derek Chauvin, the police officer who killed him. The resulting portrait is painted as “white privilege” enjoyed by Chauvin’s ancestors as opposed to the oppression experienced by Floyd’s forebears.While the book lists multiple reasons for Floyd’s downward trajectory, a single sentence about his final year in high school is key. “Like Floyd, many of the young men had grown up without fathers.” This factor has proven to be the single greatest influence on a youngster’s life.But the book looks elsewhere for explanations, making a catalogue of atrocities committed against Blacks since emancipation. After what seems like an endless stream of negativity, a positive story emerges, surprisingly just before he dies, centered on Floyd’s longstanding belief that God was watching over him.In Texas after his mother’s death in 2018, he, a girlfriend and her uncle were on an impromptu road trip between Houston and Louisiana late at night when they ran out of gas. Driving his car, Floyd was to blame, but tried to calm his friend, saying, “God’s got us.” As he and the uncle tried to push the car, a loud pickup appeared from the darkness, pulling over in front of them and “the most redneck-looking White guy” got out. The girlfriend became fearful, recalling the racist killing of James Byrd, dragged to death from a pickup twenty years earlier in the same area. But Floyd had no qualms, walking up to the stranger, shaking hands, saying they’d run out of gas. The young man was sympathetic, arranging to tow them to a gas station and putting $15 of fuel in their car so they could be on their way. The pleasant memory breaks to the grim present when Floyd speaks his last words.While the book is a solid biography, it is a flawed as history, steeped in the political divisions of the present. The book would serve well as an addendum to the 1619 Project.

“His Name is George Floyd” is a detailed and unvarnished account of George Floyd’s life, death, and aftermath.George’s personal story illustrates how both the good and the bad intertwine in the lives of so many Americans. The biographical sections (parts I and II) are passionate, dramatic, page-turners. George’s achievements, humility, resilience, and dedication to personal relationships exhibits the great potential of humanity. Simultaneously, George’s challenges (lack of role models, failing schools, police harassment and brutality) and life’s temptations (crime, drugs, sex) often lead to profound and predictable tragedy. Ultimately, whether you find his story hopeful or fatalistic, heroic or wretched will hinge on your interpretation of the balance between these forces. And on the extent to which you believe our society is learning the correct lessons from George’s existence and demise.“HIs Name…” is a biography—not a policy book. Yet, this history will inform opinions and policy conversations on both sides of the aisle regarding a host of important issues: education, policing, drugs. Expectedly, the authors have their own policy preferences. Many are predictable: increased funding for schools, better police training. But several analyses are pleasantly surprising: a wink towards licensure deregulation, an explanation of unintended ill-effects from school de-segregation. Inevitably, the sources and the authors both influence the omissions and inclusions, as well as their framing. For instance, there is a lengthy discussion about the challenges of establishing a career as a convicted felon, but only passing reference to George seeking legal employment before the age of 33. I was left wondering to what extent George pursued options other than crime at a young age and what roadblocks he may have encountered in such a pursuit. Overall, the factual history comes through clearly and is surprisingly comprehensive. “His name…” provides a common basis, albeit anecdotal, for policy conversations and debates worth engaging in.

A riveting true account of a man's life, successes and failures, struggles and challenges who knew despite what he faced would change the world.  George Floyd would become a modern day martyr in order to bring forth changes in government that have occurred and still need to happen in America. CHANGE that is necessary and brought forth as a result of systemic raciism.  We knew George Floyd the martyr, by reading this book we know George Floyd the man, the father, the athlete, his dreams, his hopes, and his challenges.  Say his name, "George Floyd!"

We all think we know George Floyd, as his life and missteps got bandied about in the news, and in our conversations in the aftermath of his death.  This book is an in depth portrait of the man behind the icon: imperfect, kind, rarely at home in his body or space, creative, deeply human, loved.It also reads like a case study on the American experience where structural racism, the aftereffects on the War on Drugs and the War on Poverty worked on the Floyd family and on Big Floyd's existence.  Will be pressing this into the hands of everyone I know.  Even if you think you know the story, I guarantee there are parts of this book that will take you by surprise, and cause you to reckon with our history and present.

A sad true-life story of our times. A well written book that puts George's life into perspective. The catch, of course, is what should each of us (including all the other Georges) do to reduce the odds of more such tragedies.

The authors give a balanced portrait of Floyd. It reinforced my suspicion that for some racial groups life chances are still different. Like gambling in casinos the house, Whites, always wins. The reader is left with hope but the impression America has a long way to go to have justice and inequality curbed. The writers deserve credit for excellent writing of a compelling story.

title: The Final Strife: Book One of The Ending Fire Trilogy
author: Saara El-Arifi
reviews: Wowza, that was one of the best books ive read in some time.The world was expertly crafted, the characters were raw and real and you couldnt help but love and hate them.I am fascinated by the reveals at the end. Now i desperately need to know more about the world before the colonizers arrived and HOW IS LOOT ONG EHAT WAS THAT?I have no chill until May. I need book two yesterday.

Every Fantasy Book you think you can find the plot easily (especially if you read as many of them as I do). This one took me on a journey that kept me guessing until the last page.I can’t say enough good things without gushing.  I am going to buy the next book and then be frosted beyond belief waiting for the third installment, and (by the grace of god) for any further installments if there are any.I’m really looking forward to many more good books from this author.  Kudos to you my lady, you are gifted.

I loved everything about this. The world that Saara El-Arifi created, politics , the magic system and love. Two young women finding about themselves, becoming stronger by the end of the book.It's own lore and stories helped create the story and tge whole vibe of this novel I could hear the drumbeats in my head.Please read own voices reviews

This is one of the Best books I've read this year. I usually won't read fantasy novels, but this one is well worth it.  Sylah, Anoora and Hassa are truly Black girl Magic.  Each come from different segments but they join together to make this story interesting.  The history of the novel, although fiction, could easily be reality.  The author  blend reality and fiction together so easily, I actually can visualize this being true. Can't wait on the sequel.  Excellent read!!

Drums. Music. Struggles. Heartache. Recovery. Self-improvement. Drugs & Rehab. Racial Oppression. Racial & Social Justice. Gender & Sexuality differences as the norm. The Final Strife: A Novel has it all and more. This is the first book in a couple of decade that I literally could not put down and I constantly crave reading more in this series. Saara El-Arifi has created a cast of characters and followed them through a harrowing journey that would challenge even the best of character who do not possess the strength and courage to fight for not only their own lives, but the lives of every other oppressed individual as well.Many, many happy congratulation to Saara El-Arifi on their debut novel and I eagerly await more books in this series. And Saara, if you happen to see this, I know that you only have this planned for a trilogy, but I would excitedly read as many books in this series as you would favor us to write.

Set in a world so well crafted that it is easy to accept, this novel kept me rapt while reading. When I wasn't reading, my mind kept coming back to the story and the concepts it explores.As a fantasy it felt fresh and new. The characters felt real, each with their own flaws and strengths.  The plot twists felt based in the story's foundation and didn't feel forced.It's a great read and I look forward to the rest of the trilogy.
Amazing world building and unique story
Best thing I've read by a new author in a long time, and I've been reading SF&F for fifty years.

title: Token Black Girl: A Memoir
author: Danielle Prescod
reviews: Danielle Prescott reveals much as she shares her own experiences with beauty and fashion as a black woman, speaking as someone coming from the fashion industry. Beginning with her childhood, she walks her readers through the encounters that shaped her ideas about being beautiful - from hairstyles to weight loss to wardrobe and everything in between. She is ruthless in exposing how she was her harshest critic, ultimately leading to an unhealthy lifestyle to maintain beauty standards she never should have had to pursue. She stops short of naming names (for the most part), but she calls out magazines, design houses, and other players in the industry who have perpetuated the idea that beauty means being tall, blonde, and unrealistically skinny.Prescod gives an honest account of when she didn't, and when she did, stand up for minorities, particularly black women, once she held positions of influence in various companies. Her revelations shouldn't be earth-shattering to anyone, and yet I suspect they will be. They are certainly uncomfortable at the least and horrifying in many cases, even while they ring true. I admire her willingness to speak out and to share her journey towards self-acceptance and healing. We all have the power to change things - even if it's just changing ourselves and how we treat and view others. Reading about the authors' experiences should make us want to try to make things better - to accept that we are all different and one kind of different isn't better than another when it comes to physical attributes.I don't write this review pretending to be an expert or to say that I understand what Danielle Prescod suffered, only to praise her efforts at raising awareness and show my admiration for her honesty and perspective, and my hopes that I've learned from her memoir and can take some small action to help change for the better.

This book made me glad I didn't grow up rich. I can relate to someone trying to make me feel stupid when, as a new hire someone else made a mistake for which I was automatically blamed by the female supervisor. My schools were mostly white. I attended a big city high school as a freshman where there were Blacks, Armenians, and other ethnicities.  Idon't remember any mean girls or racial problems, though they probably existed without my knowledge. As a new kid in a strange new environment, I didn't say much and had few friends and no enemies.  At 74, I feel like I have lived in a bubble which has just been burst, though I don't know how to improve the racist world at this point. There are very few Blacks in the part of New England where I live, though I do interact a little with Latinos. It helps that I took Spanish when we lived in California for 15 years.I hope you can find a way to have your own hugely successful company in a field you love, with equality and respect for all your employees.

This book was absolutely triggering for me. Too many of the stories were the same stories I went through and too many of the feelings I also felt growing up. I grew up half black, living most of my life with my white mom and a mostly absent African father. So we are not the same token black girl and yet we are. I am thankful I never went through the eating disorders, but I have friends who did and I know this will be a hard read for them. But I think it’s one that we ALL should read.I had to take a break from this book for a few weeks and come back, determined to see it through. There are too many uncomfortable truths in this book and I had to decide to get through them. I probably need therapy to deal with all the trauma from racism I’ve had to face in my life, but I honestly don’t think I’m quite ready to confront it all head on.Anyhow, whether I agree or disagree with the things Danielle says, I realize that systemic racism is a problem we have to keep confronting every day we live, if we want to leave the world a better place. I appreciated her candidness, the way she took ownership of her choices and the way she is seeking healing. I hope that others find the opportunity to read and reflect in the points and problems addressed in this book and work in their own lives to overcome the overt racism that media constantly shoves down our throats.

As a biracial person, I found this book... oh, how to describe this... accurate from both sides of the racial line & my family tree. I've been the Token Black Girl in white spaces and the Token White Girl in black spaces, so I couldn't wait to see what this book had to say. Some of the author's work experiences were similar to my own in the corporate world. The author and I are somewhat close in age, so many of her school-aged cultural references brought back a lot of memories. Her insights into the racial aspects of media and fashion were equally informative and saddening. Her self-awareness is inspiring. You can see the hard work she has done to better herself. Bravo! Lastly, she makes a lot of suggestions on how to improve racial equality - I deeply value her efforts here. She didn't just write about all that is imbalanced, she wrote about possible solutions to bring harmony. I rarely give 5 stars, but I believe this book deserves 7 stars. The extra 2 stars are for the solutions, and the vunerability of sharing her mental health struggles. PS The author reads the Audible version, which made it feel like a conversation versus a book. HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS BOOK!

title: Cabin Fever: The Harrowing Journey of a Cruise Ship at the Dawn of a Pandemic
author: Michael Smith
Jonathan Franklin
reviews: This is how an investigative book and investigative journalism should be written. No stone is left unturned, no one person or entity is to blame and there is factual evidence to being about every opinion Smith made in the narration of the Zaandam, a Holland America (owned by Carnival Cruise Lines) ship that departed from Buenos Aires in early March 2020, about the time the coronavirus was spreading across the globe.Not only are the journalistic aspects of this book outstanding, but so is the humanity. One can’t help but feels for the passengers and crew members portrayed in this book. That is the case whether they were infected with the virus or not. A few of the people will have a god conclusion to this nightmarish voyage, but many will not. Reading this now, nearly 3 years after the event, it’s easy to think ‘if only they knew what we know now” one will see the mistakes made. But given the lack of knowledge, especially out at sea, it is understandable even though some of the actions had disastrous results. But a reader will also be very angry with the various governments and bureaucracies- it felt like they forgot there were sick and dying people on those ships, not just carriers of some scary virus. Highly recommended reading.

This story is so important.  Critical to read through and understand what happens when we (as humans) are ill-prepared.  My hope is that the cruise ship industry has learned from the tragedies of COVID and will have new systems in place for future outbreaks or other such catastrophes at sea.Reading the story of quarantine certainly brought back my own tiny experience with COVID quarantine at home.  Stories like this one will go down in the history books for future generations as a genuine slice of what it was really like to live through a worldwide pandemic.

The authors wove diverse individual experiences with reporting. The cruise industry continually externalizers costs onto the environment, crew, and communities. Passengers and crew bore the brunt when communities and entire countries finally told the cruise ships no, you cannot dump your sick and infected on us. Yet, in 2022, people are back on cruise ships and they dump the sick and infected into communities when allowed to do so.
I cannot imagine being in a situation as described by the author. The passengers and crew are hero’s every one.

Cabin Fever is a must read for anyone you has ever been on a cruise and remembers the chaotic, frightening Covid-19 pandemic’s full fledged eruption in 2020.  This book gives an in-depth look at what happened on the Zaandam as country after country refused to allow it to dock in March/April2020 as governments tried to keep their countries Covid free (an impossible goal).  The book is extremely well written and took me back emotionally to what it felt like during the early days of the pandemic.  I cried for many of the personal stories told of crew and passengers.  The book gives an interesting look into all the personal, political and diplomatic efforts that finally allowed cruise ships to dock and discharged passengers and crews.

This book and the story of lives impacted by Covid-19 reminded me of how much of life would be forever changed beginning in 2020. These people lived through a totally different quarantine protocol than most of us. This book showed me how people lived under severe hardship. I am humbled.
Excellent read. While the focus is Covid and the cruise ship world, there are many lessons to extract from this well-written tale.

I have done more than 60 cruises and been in 110 countries in the past 70 years.  After I retired at 70 years of age six years ago I increased the number of cruises and length.  My idea was when I was old and sick I would have many memories; instead the world got sick just as my bucket list was exhausted.  This is a wonderful true to lifeBook.  I couldn’t put it down.  I have sailed on two of the ships mentioned and I couldn’t wait for the next chapter.  Very compelling and well written.  A few minor errors but very few.  Highly recommended!

title: The First Kennedys: The Humble Roots of an American Dynasty
author: Neal Thompson
reviews: I was somewhat familiar with the first Kennedys background from a biography on John Jr. The plight of the Irish I learned from a History Channel documentary (when History used to do history). It is true that the more things change, the more they stay the same. When the Irish immigrants arrived in the US, they faced much of the same challenges as the immigrants of today. Bridget was fortunate not to fall prey to a number of situations and maladies that plagued the poor. With hard work and sacrifice, she forged a life for her and her children after the death of her husband at a young age. She didn’t know that she had begun an American dynasty. This book is an interesting account of the humble beginnings of an American version of royalty. Yet another wonderful history book that isn’t taught in many schools.

Fascinating insight into the life of Irish immigrants. Amazing the amount of hatred immigrants faced, sadly still happening with other cultures. The book is very good at bringing to life the “first” Kennedys, highly recommended.

Enjoyed the book but the first 2/3s are really about what might have befallen the Kennedy's, not the Kennedy's, but the author did well with what he had.  Still there was a lot of research, its and worth one's time.

As an  American Indian Irish woman I found this an intriguing tale that must have Joe turning in his grave.  It calls in me the desire to know more about my relatives from both the Irish and Indian sides if my family. Well written.

Interesting book, if at times a little repetitive. Sometimes I found myself skimming through elements that had already been told. The book did give me the sense that the more things change, the more they stay the same.

I love reading history as a way to understand the present.  Here is a story of immigration at its best and worst — and the ever-present American desire to disparage it.  Four generations from coffin ship to the American Presidency.  Along the way, entrepreneurial skill passed down to the next generation, building wealth, and then using that wealth for the betterment of others (except for the third generation).

PJ Kennedy was the quintessential Irishman. Son of immigrants, he became a successful yet kind businessman who cares for his community of Boston immigrants from Ireland. Unlike his mercurial and arrogant son, Joseph P Kennedy he cared for the oppressed and unfortunate members of his constituency.Joe Kennedy couldn’t even attend his father’s funeral. He was too busy making movies and screwing starlets.A sad testimony to PJ and his ancestors- ain’t karma a bitch Joe ! So sad !
Product in good shape.

title: The Two Lives of Sara: A Novel
author: Catherine Adel West
reviews: The book was just heart-breaking.  I so wanted Sara to find happiness. She had it for a while but it left her life.  There are some really good people in her life who offer her hope and happiness but she just cannot stay with them. Painful memories.

More than just words on a page, this book will stay with me for a long time. A beautifully written book , haunting at times. A tale of a strong woman and the choices she makes.  We’re they right or wrong? Can we outrun our past? Can we accept unconditional love? Read it to see - you will be glad you did.

I really enjoyed this novel. West did an amazing job of painting a time period and detailing an important era in Black history, while still portraying the intimacy of a family and community wrestling with the themes we all want — hoping for a better life, protecting our children, moving past hurt and longing for love. Do yourself a favor and pick up this book!

Just now read some other reviews of the book and realized that others who read West's first novel had more insights to Sara King than I had going in cold.While I am now eager to read Saving Ruby King, I will say it didn't matter in the least. The Two Lives of Sara is a powerful, wonderfully moving story which stands well on its own.Well-written with richly drawn characters and relationships that felt real and visceral. I loved the way West draws the world of the Memphis community Sara finds herself embraced by. I was also drawn in by Sara's backstory, hinted at and revealed through letters and memories.While there is much hope and beauty in the story, heartbreak is never far removed. A beautiful, bittersweet tale that will stay with you long after you have read the final page.Highly recommended.

I spent my reading hours with this book feeling something different with every page and chapter.  I fell in love with the female characters.  I was hopeful and disappointed, again and again.  Ms. West is a unique and, yes, an intense author.  She isn’t going to let you get comfortable.  But she won’t let you forget her book either — ever.

I had a hard time getting into this book - not sure if it was the style or the way the narrative unfolded. It was highly rated by others, so I kept giving it a chance, but left about half way through. I'll probably return to this book in the future and start over because I'm sure it's pretty good. Just not for me right now.

The author's writing is clever and intentional. Many factors of life as well as wisdom is shared with the reader. US history, love, lack of love, pain, sadness, and family are just some of the topics.One of the best books I've read.
just received it today

title: Paris Daillencourt Is About to Crumble (Winner Bakes All Book 2)
author: Alexis Hall
reviews: Summary: Paris Daillencourt’s flatmate signed him up for the hit baking show Bake Expectations, and so he finds himself in the GBBO-like competition. But he’s suffering through sever undiagnosed anxiety, so he’s sure he’s going to make a mess of things with the competition and with his cute fellow competitor, Tariq Hassan.Review: I don’t think Alexis Hall can write a bad book. His writing is beautiful: it’s insightful, funny, poignant, and just really well crafted. HIs characters have depth and unique personalities—he really shines with the side characters. This is true for all of Hall’s books that I’ve read, and this one is no different.It’s odd because reading this story was difficult, and I sometimes didn’t like Paris or Tariq. But having finished it, I have these soft, affectionate feelings towards them. Paris wants to do the right thing but his anxiety keeps him so focused on himself that he can’t see how selfish he’s being. But underneath that is a funny, sweet man. And Tariq has a natural kindness and a wonderfully accepting nature—he’s pure sunshine.And yet, I can’t quite decide if I enjoyed this book or not. I mean, I did. For all of the above reasons. But this is a surprisingly difficult book. It’s marketed as a contemporary romance, a romcom even. And there are plenty of funny moments. And there is a romance running through it. But I have to agree with the other reviewers who pointed out that the main focus seems to be more on Paris’ mental health than on the romance. The two are inextricably linked because there is no way for Paris to be in a healthy relationship while his anxiety is untreated, so I can see that this is still a romance even with the mental illness plot. But Paris’ anxiety almost overwhelms the story.There were times when being in Paris’ POV (which we always are because this is a single POV story) was almost too much to bear. On multiple occasions I was almost in tears from the weight of Paris’ anxiety. I’m sure this is, in a way, a tribute to Hall’s ability to show Paris’ anxiety and how it affects his thoughts and behaviors. He convey’s Paris’ anxiety and the hopeless and helpless feelings that accompany it so well that I was feeling it too. And it wasn’t enjoyable—not that it should be. It’s just not what I usually go to a romcom for.Also, I was a little bothered by how focused Tariq was on how Paris looks. I know Tariq was good about standing up for himself when he felt Paris was being insensitive or hurtful, but it almost seemed like the only reason he wanted to be with Paris was because Paris was good-looking. And then there was the whole thing about Paris being rich. It felt as if Tariq was always holding Paris’ wealth against him even though Paris was born into it and was trying not to be an entitled jerk about it, even when he was unconsciously leaning on it. I’m sure there was some point about being self-aware and not trying to buy approval or something, but it came off more as if Tariq was being judgmental, as if he expected Paris to apologize for his wealth and upbringing. I mean, Paris couldn’t even recount a childhood memory without Tariq making it seem as if Paris were trying to rub his wealth in Tariq’s face. If you spent a vacation in Italy as a child, how can you convey that memory without talking about where you were? Is Paris just never supposed to talk about his past? What I’m saying is, if this supposed to be some sort of critique of class disparities, it doesn't work as well as it did in Rosaline Palmer Takes the Cake.So yeah. It’s a really well written book. But I have mixed emotions. It was fun to be on the set of Bake Expectations again and see Grace, Marianne, Wilford, Jennifer and Colin again. The side characters were all really fun. Tariq’s dad was a kick. I wish I had a friend like Morag—she’s a hoot and is super fierce. And no matter what, I’m glad Paris got his HFN. In the end, I do have fond feeling for this story.Note: this is a non-steamy read

The writing is beautiful, the romance is sweet, you can see why the characters are drawn together, and what pulls them apart, (and reunites them). There's moments of levity for sure, and the side characters and observations really bring humor to the book.But the absolute star of the book is the depiction of living with generalized anxiety disorder. Reading Paris's perspective was like being back inside my own head before I got medication. Which was hard, not gonna lie. I don't think I've ever read something that so thoroughly captured the all-encompassing nature of anxiety, how it blots out everything good and takes over your life and spirals itself bigger and bigger. How it lies, how it picks at you, the endless what-ifs, the catastrophizing that feels probable, and the resulting paralysis. The absolute certainty that everything good is a temporary fluke, that everything bad is deserved, that people who like you have been fooled, and one day they'll realize the truth. The desperate conflict-avoidance that only causes conflict. And overall, how hopeless everything feels. This is who you are, so you don't deserve help until you fix yourself. Other people have it worse and so you don't need meds, you just need to try harder and not inflict your whining on them. How dare you.Gods, it's all there. And it was so so hard to read. It was hard remembering being that person and having everyone around me telling me that life wasn't supposed to be this hard. That I could get help. That medication might help me more than therapy alone did. That maybe I wasn't saying enough to my therapist about how life felt and how I couldn't get out of my own way.Ultimately, I'm glad I read this book. It reminded me how far I've come. How much medicine has done for me in taking my anxiety levels down a few rungs (it's still there) and allowing me to have other emotions. How supportive my people are. And I think this book will do a lot do show people living with anxiety that there is help -- the kind Paris eventually gets with managing his anxiety better through medication and therapy -- so he can have the life he wants with his schooling and his partner. And it will do a lot for people who just don't understand why it's so much harder for some of us. Sometimes, our brains just really, chemically hate us.

I loved the way this book started, but it went sort of downhill for me after a while.At the beginning, Paris comes across as somewhat "quirky." But after reading a few chapters, his severe mental problems - much deeper than quirkiness - soon become apparent. Reading his extended inner monologues and watching his horrible depression and nearly horrible self-effacement as well as dealing with the [too] many characters really weighed this reader down. Oh! So many characters!I was truly pulling for him for about the first third of the book; and for Tariq as well. But I, as the reader, can only do so much in my imagination. Paris actually DOES "crumble" before our eyes :-/I really couldn't feel the romantic "chemistry" between Paris and Tariq. It COULD have been there but for Paris's many issues and Tariq's very set "old-fashioned" values. On the other hand, I loved some of the side characters like Tariq's less "old-fashioned" father and Morag, Paris's snarky, witty housemate (who lives in Paris's "deluxe" London apartment for nearly free!).But these two, along with a very few other minor actors, are not enough to rescue the book from a plethora of characters.Toward the end of the book, soon after signing up for therapy (at the near insistence of Tariq and Morag), Paris's mental state does start improving.But, for me, it was too little; too late :-/I don't think I'll be reading the other books in the "Winner Bakes All" series.

title: Sleepwalk: A Novel
author: Dan Chaon
reviews: It was weird to identify with Billy, the protagonist who is a bit psychotic, a bit sociopathic, a bit druggie, a bit hippie, a bit dreamer, and a bit murderer. But I definitely identify with the loner in Billy, the sleepwalker. He’s been a survivor, but longs for true connection and does finally get it, or gets as close to it as may be possible in this doomed world.I’m happy simply to have finished a book! My last three or four have been duds, so that’s some kind of good recommendation, I guess. May try another Don Chaon book.

I went into this book, having forgotten what it was about except for a vague idea it was likely to be a bit strange. And it was that: weird but good. I never lost interest in the story, and wanted to see how it all turned out. Because it felt like the worst things going on today IRL were extrapolated out into the future of this story, it was kind of depressing to think, "yeah, I can see how that could happen."

I liked this read for sure ...possibly a bit dark and pessimistic for some but the main character is intriguing,even if a kind of psycho oriented person. Like other authors,ie,Patricia Highsmith,this tale can make the reader dwelling in a paranoid world but Dan is a very good writer and the theme of 'sperm donors' is relevant in our times as a real issue.......... Go ahead cleveland----i would give it 4 1/2 if could just 1/2 star off for the lack of much humor and un-ending darkness of the atmosphere ---even the bright ending seems dark as you will see......

Blurring the experience of humanities near loss and defeat. There is no one person that solves everything. There are friendly moments of normalcy but the deadly game is at play. The main actor keeps falling and barely finds peace. He really likes doing drugs. But the ending leaves you hopeful.
The last Chaon book I read (which was years ago) was You Remind Me of Me and I really liked it.  This book, while an interesting read, just never grabbed me to the point of being 5 stars.

It’s true. Raymond Chandler and Kurt Vonnegut made a baby. And its name is Sleepwalk. From the first few pages, I was enthralled by author Dan Chaon’s ability to create an antihero of such depth—such longing—that I nearly forgot Will Bear is a sociopath. Yeah. Among his many side jobs, he kills people.As you wend your way through the backroads of a slightly futuristic America, you realize that the person Billy is was mainly due to his random, haphazard childhood. That and a sometime mom who herself had sociopathic tendencies. Like his mother, when the protagonist takes someone out, it’s not personal. Instead, it’s necessary.When Will learns that he might have a biological daughter, things get even more interesting as the revelation turns his world upside down. There were times when I pictured the character as Philip Marlowe chasing down clues. Other times, I recalled some of the funniest moments in novels, such as Player Piano and Cat’s Cradle. But hey, that’s me.Sleepwalk is a hard book to categorize. If I had to sum it up, I’d say it’s crime fiction with some laughs, mainly at Will’s expense. And like him, the other characters are as real as they get. Truthfully, though, The novel is not for everyone. Just saying.If you’re into authors who write to market, then this book may not seem like a slam dunk. But, on the other hand, if you give it a chance, I promise it will open your eyes to addictive storytelling that doesn’t play by the rules. If there was a way, I’d give this book six stars.

I bought "Sleepwalk"  based on Amazon's recommendation and while I enjoyed the beginning and the main character I thought the book dragged.  The premise was great but I just could not get into it after the first 100 pages as nothing really happened.  Lots of drugs, trips down memory lane, etc., but a coherent story that was interesting?  No.  "Trippy" is a good word to describe the book and while that's NOT a bad thing it just wasn't for me.  I get why people like it so I'm not going to pan it since I loved the authors "Ill Will" but it seemed to me that the plot just meandered... and meandered... and meandered.  To each his own, though!

Dan Chaon is a singular and important voice in American fiction, exploring in his unmistakable tone and style themes of family, connection, the inner workings of personal identity, the corrosive power of technology, and our country's increasingly troubling turns toward corporatization, radicalization, and paranoia. This latest book is his best yet. Will "Billy" Bear - who goes by too many aliases to count - is an operative for a vast criminal syndicate with the deliciously mundane name of Value Standard Enterprises. He roams the country in a camper van, his only companion a scarred-up pitbull that he rescued from a dogfighting ring, taking calls and jobs of varying levels of criminality from a plethora of burner phones, and the "Friends" of the syndicate who know how to reach him. Into this lonely vigil, however, comes the voice of a young woman named Cammie who claims to be his daughter - but is she real, or is it just another deadly trap being laid for a man who has stayed assiduously "off the grid" his entire life? As Billy tries to sort out the truth there, and the uncomfortable truths of the near-future dystopia he lives in, the story only gets better, and weirder, and more compelling. And somehow, through all of this dysfunction, immorality, and technological squalor, the author finds a way to deservedly pluck our heartstrings as well.

title: NSFW: A Novel
author: Isabel Kaplan
reviews: A book with a title like NSFW is practically daring you to read it, especially at work. YOLO. But NSFW is more than a book with a buzzy title; it's also an incredibly ambitious and timely novel about rape culture, and what working in Hollywood was like prior to the widespread progression of the #MeToo movement in 2017 following the Harvey Weinstein allegations.The heroine in NSFW is never named, but she's a young Jewish girl living in Hollywood. Her mother was a feminist lawyer famous for taking on rape cases and empowering women to confront their attackers, but now she's having an existential crisis, hover parenting her adult daughter while self-medicating with expensive beauty treatments and questionably prescribed medications. She is good for one thing, though: her connections. She's old friends with a higher-up at a production studio and is able to finagle our protagonist a job.Our heroine quickly proves herself competent and a little cut-throat. She's insecure but willing to do what needs to be done, and she knows who her allies are. Which is why it's so shocking to her when quiet whispers begin to circulate about certain men in the studio taking advantage of their power to get what they want from the women who work there. She feels valued, and respected (mostly), so surely those other women can't be right? Maybe they did something or maybe they misunderstood the situation. Those are the lies we tell ourselves to believe that we're safe. But in a culture that discourages victims from speaking out and places the burden of proof and the brunt of the blame on the wronged, nobody is ever really safe.I LOVED this book, okay? I can't believe people aren't talking about it. Or that the ratings are so low! No, this isn't a book with a neat and tidy ending, and often it feels bleak, but the way it captures workplace culture and the so-called post-sexism culture of the early 2010s, when people felt way too optimistic about the all too grim future, is pitch-perfect. The heroine is believably flawed, and I feel like her struggle to come to terms with her own internalized misogyny and the way that she labors under her mother's mixed messages and emotional abuse are so well done. Feminism isn't a set of clear-cut principles and it's a constant journey of self-betterment, so I love seeing books that tackle the process of going through that legwork. It's also just a really good and gossipy story that's hard to put down. In some ways, it reminded me a lot of another "flawed feminist" book I just read, POST-TRAUMATIC.P.S. The blurb says that this is a debut work, but it isn't. The author published a previous book in 2007, also set in LA. After reading this one, I may have to buy it. It's YA but it looks like it's on the more mature end of the YA spectrum.4.5 to 5 out of 5 stars
This book didn't go anywhere. Not recommended, its not feminist, its not entertaining, its not really anything. Waste of money.
I really enjoyed this. The writing was clear, the characters seemed familiar and were intriguing throughout. I would strongly recommend.
Funny, sad, entertaining, and insightful.  A great read.
Sharp, smart, funny witty and ultimately much more.... READ IT!

This was complex and intense and so compelling.The Weinstein plot is what is most recognizable. But I was most intrigued by the mother/daughter relationship, convos around nepotism, and what women have to endure and put aside to get ahead.I liked how lowkey unlikable every character was, and how I had to constantly question my own ethics based of decisions they were making.Is it perfect no, but for well written Me Too-esque book, this is it.Also if you watched Entourage and always wanted Ari Gold to get his comeuppance or to experience the show from a woman’s perspective, this is the book for you.

You follow an unnamed female narrator who is trying to grow in the entertainment industry and witness the sexism and misogyny revolve around the work environment and how fellow female colleagues have to navigate through that.  This wasn't my favorite read that focuses on this subject matter, but I still liked it.I received an advanced reader copy from Henry Holt & Company and NetGalley. All review opinions are my own.

I'm halfway through this book and wondering if there's a point? A Harvard grad returns home to Los Angeles, gets a job at a TV network, has a codependent relationship with her mom etc... There's nothing to care about. I don't want to waste my time to read the rest. It should also have been a sign not to read the book when you haven't heard of any of the authors that praise it on the cover.

title: The Year of the Horses: A Memoir
author: Courtney Maum
reviews: I read it for the reading challenge. I did appreciate the first half of the book where she details her struggles as a mom, wife, and author. I can empathize with some of her struggles and even a bit of the journey to overcome them. No one talks about the hardships of being a modern mother without anyone around to help you through this brand new experience of raising a child. We are just supposed to know what to do and have our entire lives together in the meantime. Enter anxiety and depression and all the fun things that come with them. This book digs into that part of motherhood and I was so relieved to read that I wasn't alone in feeling these things. Now, the part where she attempted to weave in the healing aspect of horses was a little harder for me to get into. I AM a horse girl and I have been since I was a child. I guess my disconnect to the author is her fear of the animal and her unwillingness to be the leader in any horse and rider relationship that she had. So while she did learn some valuable lessons like confidence, relaxing, having fun, and getting in shape, she still never changed that dynamic. Her last horse story was about being run away with on a borrowed mare and a string of ponies. To me, I don't think she ever really learned what she needed to because she STILL struggles with that fear of horses after all those years. Anyway, the second half of this book was pretty discombobulated, and she ended it like she just gave up on figuring out the best conclusion for it. Like a rage-quit kind of thing. I get that it was so hard to put all of this down on paper, for the public to read, but I think this book deserved more attention to the last half. I'd give it three and a half out of five stars. At least it's a short book.

This memoir opens in 2016 when Maum was thirty-seven years old and her daughter two. Her debut novel had been published the year her daughter was born, but her second novel, which was under contract, was due soon. Then it was late. The demands of care for her two-year-old had become consuming and frustrating. Her relationship with her husband was strained. Insomnia muddled everything. The overdue draft had two horse people characters:  a dressage champion and his racehorse-breeding mother. The novel was about the experience of touch deficit in a tech mediated digital age. What were these horse people doing in the draft? Maum knew the novel wasn’t working, but she didn’t want to cut these characters. She drove two hours into northern Massachusetts from her home in the Berkshires, for research, to interview a famous dressage trainer. There she found herself being pulled back into relationship with horses, an orbit she’d left nearly thirty years earlier. The Year of the Horses tells the story of how Maum’s renewed connections with horses and related changes in herself saved her marriage—she confesses to having been unfaithful—how they saved her relationship with her daughter, her own mental health, and her writing.—Maum’s debut novel was the inaptly titled I’m Having So Much Fun Here Without You (2014, Touchstone, 331pp.). The novel is about estrangement, the male narrator’s infidelity, and the psychological and interpersonal struggle to recover."I married my lover, time turned her into my sister. Truly, badly, I want my lover back. But we’ve twisted each other with our unspoken failures and our building scorn."In this novel, Maum gave a nuanced, sympathetic portrayal of her unfaithful protagonist.—The central storyline of The Year of the Horses moves through 2016 into 2018, from the opening scene, before Maum’s reunion with horses, until after she had gained basic proficiency in the dangerous sport of polo. The narrative weaves in strands from Maum’s childhood, adolescence, and young adulthood. Horse people and others who have known closeness with non-human mammals will resonate with this story. And the horses are not merely incidental. But running through the narrative is Maum’s perceptive reflection on her past and her generosity toward…well, really everyone a lesser person might have blamed for her struggles. Instead, she blames herself, and then shows us how to move beyond that."What was I so furious about? Why did I hate my mellow husband? Leo had some serious spatial awareness issues…and a selective attention span, but he was a good father and a dedicated one, tireless in fact…. Our sensual life had dwindled to once-in-a-blue-moon physical communions that made me feel embarrassed, but when I turned the tables, what desire did I show him? What efforts was I making? How come everything was Leo’s fault all the time?"—When Maum was six years old, her parents finally gave in to her pleas for a horse. She rode for three glorious years, changing horses as her skills developed and she won ribbons and trophies for her riding and jumping. But her little brother’s illness, and her parents’ fracturing marriage and divorce, brought the riding to a halt when she was nine years old. Maum struggled with insomnia as a child and as an adolescent with anorexia. When the memoir begins, she is mired in a severe depression—and pulled by a longing to be loved, touched, known.—Maum’s second novel, Touch (2017, Putnam, 303pp.) prompts more LOLs than her debut. With playful humor and satirical elements, it is set in the near future where high tech is ascendant. The protagonist, Sloane, is a thirty-something trend forecaster who has opted not to have children. At a point when she has become conflicted about her own touch deficit, she proposes to her boss, offhandedly, that his tech company could produce “empathy tots” for the childless. “‘[Robotic] Kids you can turn on and off,’” because childless people are touched less often. Touch is about the desire to recover physical closeness, to pull back from having only digital contact with virtual connections. Maum’s first two novels are not about loss. They begin when the loss has already happened. Both are about the possibility of a recovery of closeness: in a marriage and in the larger culture of digitally mediated connection.—In The Year of the Horses, Maum addresses several challenges, for instance:  How to be a professionally accomplished person who is also mother to a strong-willed, curious child. How to be an artist married to another but different sort of artist. And how to accept, as a perfectionist, becoming only tolerably good at a sport that she played for fun. In these and other ways, she needed to do better for her husband and daughter than she had experienced as a child."I had never thought about how upset it made me that whether I was at my mother’s or my father’s, my parents let me hurt myself, how unloved it made me feel, until my therapist asked me if my parents had shown me any neglect."Once, when the deadline for the second novel was closing in, she and her family took a vacation while living and working in France. Maum recalled:"I wanted to be kind. I wasn’t. Looking back with the lens of years between me and that arid property, I see now that I wasn’t able to vacation because I’d cut myself off from the possibility that a family could bring joy. Work brought joy, and because the writing wasn’t going well, there could be no joy."—Maum’s third novel, Costalegre, (2019, Tin House, 218pp.), breaks from her first two, both of which work well as audiobooks. Plot has gone almost silent. This novel is both less “realistic” and less hopeful than her first two. But there is a through line. Lara, the narrator, has just turned fifteen years old. She has come with her American heiress mother, Leonora Calaway (based on Peggy Guggenheim), to a coastal Mexican jungle. Leonora brought seven avant-garde painters and writers she rescued from pre-World War II Europe. The novel consists of diary entries:  letters, reflections on people and events, lists of likes and dislikes, notes about lush vegetation and flowers, descriptions of dreams, etc. The narrative that does emerge, though, has the following threads:  Leonora and her surrealists are waiting anxiously for a ship smuggling the paintings she collected in Europe for her planned museum. She is attending more to her “rescues” and their current work than to her daughter. She hasn’t arranged for a tutor for Lara. Leonora hardly notices when Lara is absent. Lara becomes infatuated with an artist not of their group. That fictional character represents the historical Constantin Brancusi, sculpting in the novel even though the surrealists at Leonora’s house think he has stopped working. Brancusi was fifty-two years old when Hitler and Nazi troops marched into Austria, halfway into the novel. Lara aches over Leonora’s maternal neglect, and she chafes at the older artist’s responses to her attentions. She desires deeply to be loved, touched, known.—One of the most enjoyable chapters in The Year of the Horses occurs late in the memoir. It seems almost irrelevant to the larger story about horses. Maum convinced her reluctant husband they should adopt, sight unseen, a rescue cat that turns out to have been, not a kitten, as advertised, but a four-year-old who had been abused and abandoned. Maum tells the story of picking it up and bringing it home and how they dealt with the effects of its traumas. This chapter is a delight. Maum here and throughout this memoir is funny and heartwarming without being sentimental. And this apparently irrelevant chapter hits what may be the main theme of the memoir: How do we make mistakes? And how do we recover from them without making things worse?—Maum’s most recent book before this memoir compiles advice for debut authors nearing the publishing process. Its title gives a preview of the book’s comprehensiveness: Before and After The Book Deal: A Writer’s Guide to Finishing, Publishing, Promoting, and Surviving Your First Book (2020, Catapult, 347pp.). This handbook is encyclopedic. Debut authors would have almost no way of knowing many of its details. As a reference work, it can supply an overview but is probably most useful a chapter at a time, when writers are at the relevant stage in their process. One hundred and ninety-six writers and publishing professionals are listed in an appendix as interviewed and/or quoted.—WARNING:  There are a couple of heartbreaks late in The Year of the Horses. I took them pretty hard. I wanted Maum to get sentimental, and she didn’t do it. So I got sentimental on my own, in the privacy of my reading this wonderful memoir. Maum’s renewed love of horses is the centerstage story, but its unmistakable backdrop is her generous nature, her sense of humor, her keen self-awareness, and her love of life. She takes us through her “unrelenting, steely-nerved perfectionism” and the many ways she has been too hard on herself, through her generosity to all those in her life she might have blamed, to the best to which most of us mortals can aspire:  a healthy if imperfect life.

Courtney Maum's first memoir is a must-read. From the minute it was delivered until I finished it, I couldn't put it down. I'm normally an ebook reader, but I ordered the hardcover. I'm glad I did because the 80s nostalgia was strong. I marked up the margins with notes & stars instead of highlighting in Kindle.Her recollection of personal experiences (both the wins & losses) throughout her childhood, teens, and adulthood spoke true to me. We've actually lived in the same areas, so I felt my own nostalgia reading her stories (I was actually pregnant in Paris & New England at the same time). Don't worry if you haven't because she beautifully describes all her locations so to bring you into her own memories (think Dumbledore's Pensieve).Although I'm not a "horse girl"...more like a "car girl" or "cat lady", I loved learning all about horses...specifically the women polo players. I'm definitely going to quote "SHOULDERS LIKE A QUEEN, HIPS LIKE A WHORE!" whenever I need to readjust myself.I found this memoir to be full of courage, bravery, and honesty (even alluding to her own narrator bias). I can only hope that her experiences and story help others to find ways to prioritize their own self-care and mental health.Throughout my teens and occasionally as a young adult I would play tennis. Two summers ago I started teaching one of my children but recently started to take lessons again on my own. Tennis to me is what horses are to Maum: something joyful that is completely my own. It challenges and delights me. If you like those two things, then you should read THE YEAR OF THE HORSES as soon as possible.

I was immediately drawn in by this title. As a rider myself I understand the deep healing and connection one can find in the equine world. As I made my way through this deeply felt and succinctly communicated memoir, I felt the heart and soul of a woman on the brink, searching. She is recognizable in her struggles with depression, motherhood, and seeking her own identity.I loved this memoir and the reminder of our connection to one another and to the animals we love. The 80s references definitely added to the allure for me (especially Lisa Frank). Ha
Book was boring and her ego centric focus was off putting.

title: The Other Mother: A Novel
author: Rachel M. Harper
reviews: The story was great some jumping around but it was to describe each player in the book. Could have used a little better ending.

This is a story of family relationships and difficult decisions. It unfolds with great intrigue, each revelation pulling the reader in more deeply. Exactly the right book for another long Covid summer, in fact for any time, and any place. A most compelling read — I couldn’t put it down.

I’m so in awe of this book—its scope and warmth and vulnerability, the texture of relationship and interiority brought to each character, the deeply relatable questions that emerge. The novel’s structure—with each character given their own section/voice—feels revelatory. Each page is a treat, and I was so sad when it ended! Many tears shed reading this gem.

This is a beautiful story about an unconventional relationship during a.time when same sex adoptions were frowned upon.  Specifically in the.African American culture.  Although reading the intimate paragraphs may be uncomfortable for some, I'm glad they're part of the story.The.love, feelings and care for the characters weave.through the pages, complex as.tney.usually can be.  Congrats to the author.

This book was very good. It’s about family and choices. How the choices you make when young can dominate your life. It’s also about family and expectations and living the life you want to live. It’s also about being successful and the commitment that takes. The Other Mother is very enjoyable.

I’m 50 pages in and I can’t put it down. I’ve already teared up. I’m enthralled. Her dialogue! Her details! I want to stop bc I don’t want it to end. I don’t want to have to wait until her next book. (I felt this way after her last book.)
This was a great first summer read.  I could hardly put it down.  I was a little disappointed in the ending, but everything is not always sorted out perfectly in life.
This book was,a page turner. I loved getting to know each character. By the time I was near the end, I cried. That's the kind if connection I had for those people

title: How to Kill Your Family: A Novel
author: Bella Mackie
reviews: I wasn't certain I would finish this book. I didn't like anyone. I didn't find it to be laugh out loud as suggested by a review. I kept going though. The more I read, the more intrigued I became. The book became impossible to put down. I stayed up past midnight reading it. It was much better than I thought it would be. There were twists that surprised me. It is with that in mind that I would suggest you skip the reviews and just get the book. Oh! By the end of the book, I did come to appreciate Grace.

I was very interested in the book because of the cover and the title. Big letters and a black and pink cover screamed at me as I browsed for books. It looked like a promising story. And for the most part, it delivered an entertaining read.Grace, a twenty-something, currently in jail for murder, tells her story of how she has committed multiple murders, but not the murder she is currently in jail for.The plot intrigued me. Each murder she planned and committed took its time, some much longer than others. But it was clear to me that a lot of thought and detail went into that part of the story. Grace has her reasons and makes sure she has her opportunity. One by one she can cross a name off her kill-list.I enjoyed the story, and I had fun reading about Grace's journey. I especially liked the planning and the executing of her plans, but I did not really like her other "normal" life stuff.And then came the final chapters of the story. The part where it is made clear why she is in prison and the conclusion of her story. I didn't like those parts. I would have liked a different ending, but it didn't end well for me to give it more than 3 stars.
The writing was lovely, without making a big show of it, and the way the theme changed with each target Grace pursues really keeps you engaged with the story.

The twist in this was totally unseen! Great story, although I could have ABSOLUTELY done without any of the white male bashing and the woke agenda crap. I ALMOST stopped reading, but the story was that good.
It was a little hard to get started for me. It started a little slow but once I got a little further in it really did it really grabbed me. A very good book.
Didn’t like the ending, other than that great book. It was funny, dark, captivating and a joy to read. I just wish the ending was different 🤷🏻‍♀️

I was in the DR when I meet a woman who recommended this book. I have mixed feelings about this book. The story itself was good, it has a lot of slow moments. I think sometimes authors just need to fill the pages with fluff and then they are only allowed 5 pages for an ended. The ending was disappointing. Why does a man always have to ruin a woman's good time? I can see this book turned into a Hulu limited series special. If you need a beach read, this is your book.
Holds your interest.

title: Thank You for Listening: A Novel
author: Julia Whelan
HarperAudio
reviews: I struggled with how to rate thus book.  I wanted to give it 3 1\2 stars but had to round up to four. First, the cover, does this book a great disservice.  I read the book in response to one of the Kindle challenges. None of the books really spoke to me and I chose this one because it was on sale for $2.99.  I would never have paid the full asking price for an unknown to me author and would normally never  even looked at the synopsis because I judged it on the cover.  I only found the book because it was required reading and it was the cheapest option.I liked the story. I really enjoyed the text conversations between the main character and the love interest.  But, I ended up skimming most of the last half of the book.  I think it's my fault not the authors because the book was well written  in general hence the 4 stars.  I did have issues with the overall feel and flow of the book but can't report them without spoilers.Spoilers below.............I found the book... Depressing?  I'm not sure that's the right response.  It has a happy ending.  But, I read for escapism. This book just kept making me sad.  The dying grandmother with memory issues, the cheating father, the money and housing issues,  the sadness and emotional toil was real and it just kept building.I reached my breaking point when the main character and her father had a massive fight over money and long term care of the grandmother in FRONT of her.  Later the grandmother attempts suicide and gets significantly worse memory wise.  That punch is followed by the heroine not winning a award she expected, meeting the hero face to face  for the "first" time and having an epic fight over the lies both had told. Then the best friend telling her she didn't get the movie role she expected because basically she wasn't disfigured as much or as popular as someone else and the heroine having another epic fight with the friend.  It was to much....  I started  skipping and never looked backMy third issue is the heroine lost her on screen acting career after walking into a air plane propeller.  She has a scar on her face and lost an eye and her shoulder was also damaged. The story was just a little to close to the actual story of a model who was injured in a similar situation.  We find out the story of her injury about half way through the book.  From that point on I had the real life incident and individual in mind and couldn't separate it from the fictional heroine.Then the author doubles down by having the heroine lose the acting role the friend arranged for her to get back into the business to ... wait for it....  A young social media star who lost her arm to a shark attack at 16.  Once again the similarity to actual events and individuals completely jarred me out of the story.I believe most of my issues are my own and not a technical flaw of the authors. However, I'm writing a review for readers and know that many readers are like me and may be overwhelmed by the suffering and drama in the book.  I normally read urban fantasy, sci-fi, mystery, and some romance.  The book does have romance and a happy ending it's just really rough getting there.

I have always loved listening to Whelan narrate books and I have listened to A LOT of them. So it was a no brainer to pick up this book.(kindle) She writes with an easy pace. And even as romancey as this book is it's GOOD! A genre I don't typically read but this year I have been switching things up and this book is a great one. Can't wait for a movie adaptation!!Someone buy me a physical copy of this please? I'll send you my address :)

THANK YOU FOR LISTENING is about a an audio book narrator, Sewanee, that started out on steamy romances and eventually became the go to voice for best sellers and nonfiction.  On the other side of the story is a male romance narrator Brock McNight much sought after mystery man in the audiobook world.But they come from circumstances that have broken them.  The secondary characters in the story - best friends, Nick, Sarah, Alice, grandmother, parents, employers, etc. all have their hope of helping the broken characters mend but it’s ultimate up to them to figure out what is holding them back.It’s a well written story with just the right amount of teases and twists to keep me turning the pages.  Our main characters are complex, flawed and so interesting.  Good book.

Loved it.  Loved hearing about the technical aspects of audiobooks…and Swan’s use and understanding of the English language.  Loved the emotional ups and downs of the book.  My only criticism is, I thought the last 15-20% dragged a bit…but to be fair, that part was necessary to wrap up all the details in the story.

Julia Whelan is a highly respected audiobook narrator and this book uses that as a starting point. I'm not a romance reader but this feels like a very sweet romance to me. She takes the tropes and gives them a spin. She also has another novel that I haven't read.

I liked the characters. They went through some ups and downs, but I did like seeing them come together and grow as people. It was interesting seeing the job and I liked the setting. The romance is definitely a slow burn, but still good.

This is my first book by this author and I've heard good things about this book. It was a good read. I loved that it is about audiobook narrators.Sewanee is such an interesting character. She's had an accident when she was an actress that led her to narrating audiobooks. Her backstory is interesting and you find out more and more as you read. I love her friendship with Adaku and her love for her grandmother was touching. I have to admit I got frustrated with her by the middle of the book. Her reactions to Nick and their one night stand at the beginning of the book was understandable. I felt her reactions to the revelation of who Brock was and the crazy coincidences was a bit harsh. I did enjoy the last quarter of this book and her time with her mother.I loved the messages between Sewanee and Brock in the beginning as they work on narrating a book together. When they finally meet, it was everything I hoped for and more.The last part of the book definitely made the story for me. There was actual growth between both Nick and Sewanee towards the end of the book. It was a good ending.Overall, I enjoyed this book and the concept of the story. It was different and interesting to see the behind the scenes look of audiobook narrating. It was a good romance read that has all the tropes.

title: The Community: A Memoir
author: N. Jamiyla Chisholm
reviews: N. Jamiyla Chisholm was only two-years-old when her mother quit her job and converted to Islam while joining her husband in what was considered to be an exclusive Muslim society in Brooklyn.The warm, affectionate, and seemingly devoted mother that Jamiyla had known up to that point would change once they entered the doors of this "community," a place where Jamiyla would be separated from her mother for extended periods of time and where she would be placed under the care of disciplinarian "ums" who quickly grew tired of her emotional neediness and persistent desire to see her mother. Dwight York, also known as the self-proclaimed Imam Isa, would, as is nearly always true of cults, exact absolute control within this community and instead of a spiritual haven this community became a place of controlled abuse and unspeakable secrets.40 years later, Jamiyla needed to resolve her issues around this experience and this resolution, of course, ended up in her telling the story through this book. While her mother, Ummi, had no desire to return to this place it was, at least on some level, an honoring of her daughter's needs that she at least seems to have partially participated in the writing of this book."The Community" is Jamiyla's story of her family's life inside and outside this cult and the aftermath of life for the fracturing of the family and the years that would follow including the impact of 9/11. The film is a journey through Black history and identity and also one of the personal betrayals that are so often a part of life inside a cult."The Community" was an Amazon First Read during the month of May 2022 in advance of its June 1st release.A journalist by profession now, Chisholm has crafted a story here that weaves together both her personal memories and her interviews with some of those involved in this journey. While much of "The Community" reads as if it is all her memory, a weakness in the writing, the truth is that closer review does reveal it's not always told through the voice of her childhood lens. Part of the difficulty with the book is that while it occasionally offers great detail of Chisholm's own insights and feelings during this time, it seldom offers much in the way of insights into life inside this cult or the actual aftermath of being under the control of a man who would eventually be convicted of racketeering, child sexual abuse, rape, conspiracy, and fraud and sentenced to 135 years.This makes sense, of course, since much of the story is coming from someone who was a child during these years and actually was not privy to much of this information. While she knew that she didn't have access to her mother or father, she didn't necessarily know why or where they actually were during these times. She knew that she was supervised by disciplinarians who seemed to have an abusive disdain for her, but she knew very little about the organizational structure of this cult.In other words, there was a lot that Chisholm didn't know about The Community and that lack of knowledge hinders a full-on immersion into this book that offers more casual reflections than actual in-depth insights.As someone who grew up similarly in a cult, though not a Muslim one, I'm in many ways the target reader for this book (though I do believe it's much more targeting Black readers). However, I had a hard time connecting with the material and often felt like Chisholm's ongoing lack of resolution radiates throughout the pages. While there's certainly no obligation to write an inspirational story or happy ending, especially if there isn't particularly one, there is a necessity to write a story that somehow engages with the reader. I struggled with that engagement here but still felt tremendous empathy for this child who has been so deeply wounded, and in some ways appears to be still so deeply wounded, by the actions of her parents.The politicization in the book, which is especially prominent toward the book's end, is certainly important in terms of cultural insight but feels extraneous within the context of this memoir that has up until this angle is introduced been exclusively about this cult and the fractures within Chisholm's family. It was introduced abruptly and isn't fully fleshed out enough to be truly effective.Overall, I more appreciated "The Community" than enjoyed it and never really felt like I gained insights into this cult, these people, or even how all of this has shaped Chisholm's life journey now. Basic facts, such as how long they were actually in the cult and a timeline for it, are largely ignored here in favor of a tapestry feelings over facts. The feelings are certainly important in giving this story emotional resonance, however, I came away from the experience largely dissatisfied emotionally and intellectually. Interestingly enough, at one point it occurred to me that Chisholm largely writes here like she reports experiencing her childhood - emotionally detached and with a tremendous wall that keeps things from going deeper.The end result is a book that is modestly engaging yet never completely immersive. "The Community" is a book that tells a harrowing story yet never actually feels harrowing. It's a book that wants us to understand one child's experiences and how that experience and culture shaped her, yet Chisholm still seems hesitant to fully reveal those experiences and that culture.The compound for the United Nation of Nuwaubians has long been torn down. Obviously, the impact of its presence lingers on in the memories, wounds, and scars of those men, women, and children who were impacted by their years of involvement. While "The Community" may not have quite the impact one would have hoped, it's still an important and revealing story with hope and a long due healing between a daughter and the mother she never completely understood.

I listened to the audio version of this book and found it to be very interesting. I think that it had the potential to be excellent, but there were a few areas in the story that needed to be tightened up and explained further. The last few pages of the book did that and talked about the underlying theme of love, but I think that could have been incorporated throughout the book. Nevertheless, it is an interesting story.

Overall I enjoyed this book. I found myself wanting to read or listen in chunks and then taking time to allow the material to absorb. This book deals with heavy topics in many layers. I struggled during the telling of the author's experiences at The Community however. I understand why it was presented the way it was, but retelling such detailed feelings and understandings from the perspective of a 2 year old is unrealistic and it distracted my focus during these parts.This is an important story of enduring trauma, resilience, and hope.

This book was not what I expected from reading the write up. I expected to learn about York and his movement. York is barely mentioned and the movement has very little detail. The book followed a family that had been pulled into the community and all that followed over the next 30 years.
A very interesting, yet devastating memoir, that is well written and is a pretty easy read.  I think if you are on the fence about reading it, you should read it. Its good.

A recounting of the pain and suffering endured for two years in the Muslim Community of Imam Isa (Dwight York) by the author as a toddler, how it affected her relationship with her mother, and how the relationship was repaired.  Much more about what motivated her parents to enter the Community and become Muslim and the lingering effects of racism and White Supremacy in the USA.

I am always interested in hearing the stories of people's lives and how they become who they are. I somewhat identify with Chisholm in that the church I grew up in was deemed a cult. I didn't know this until I became an adult. Reading her journey made me relive moments that made my heart rate accelerate. Times and incidents that forever shape and scar our lives and yet,  here we are. As frustrating and at times scary as it is, our stories must be told to be kept alive. I am going to look up Dwight York.

From the point of view of a three year old, we jump to talking to her mom about ‘the Community’, a place black Muslims seemed to have been drawn to. It was viewed as a cult later. Of course anytime there’s only one person controlling everything it rife for egotistical people. Ok, Men.To this add feeling alone in a culture to finding a place you hope you can call ’family’. Of course, that’s what gangs do also.Either way I found it an interesting book.

title: Such Big Dreams: A Novel
author: Reema Patel
reviews: Rhaki has been given a chance to leave the orphanage and work for a woman who pays her for office work and simple errands to help her get by in the Slums.  She becomes acquainted with a Canadian going to Harvard that works in the office as an intern.  She is asked to share the sights of the city for pay and gives her the idea that she could go to college.  Some of her dangerous past comes back to haunt her, as she  dreams of overcoming the financial obstacles.
This story blew me away.  Original and honest, gritty and compelling.  Expert storytelling in ways you couldn’t expect.  Highly recommend!
